revision.text:
[[File:Sweet Spot Cafe Shoreline.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The Sweet Spot Cafe in [[Shoreline, Washington]]]]
A '''bikini [[barista]]''' is a person who prepares and serves [[coffee]] drinks while dressed in scanty attire such as a [[bikini]] or [[lingerie]]. In the United States, this marketing trend (sometimes referred to as '''sexpresso'''<ref name="seattimesjan97"/><ref name="cbsfeb97"/> or '''bareista'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.punemirror.in/article/5/2009022720090227034756607de1e0b4b/Bareista.html |title=Bare-ista, News – |work=[[Pune Mirror]] |date=2009-02-27 |accessdate=2013-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131227070836/http://www.punemirror.in/article/5/2009022720090227034756607de1e0b4b/Bareista.html |archivedate=2013-12-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bareista.com/ |title=Bareista.com Home |publisher=Bareista.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130712034955/http://www.bareista.com/ |archivedate=2013-07-12 |df= }}</ref>) originated in the [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]] area in the early 2000s. Similar phenomena have appeared in countries such as [[Chile]] and Japan since at least the 1980s.<ref name="cbs1">{{cite news | url= http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/02/05/business/main6176773.shtml | title= Are Bikini Baristas Getting Too Steamy? | agency= Associated Press | work= [[CBS News]] | date= February 5, 2010 | accessdate= March 9, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100208155137/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/02/05/business/main6176773.shtml | archivedate= 8 February 2010 | deadurl= no | df= }}</ref>
== Development of concept == Espresso drive-through stands and coffee outlets are numerous in the greater Seattle area,<ref>{{citation|title=Washington's Weird Bikini Barista Culture|author=[[Lindy West]]|date=February 5, 2014|work=[[Jezebel]]|url=http://jezebel.com/washingtons-weird-bikini-barista-culture-1516001624}}</ref> so much so that coffee stands that have fully clothed employees often advertise themselves as "family friendly".<ref>{{citation|title=Everett officials consider dress code for bikini baristas|date=April 8, 2017|publisher=Associated Press|via=US News and World Report|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/washington/articles/2017-04-08/everett-officials-consider-dress-code-for-bikini-baristas}}</ref> The exact inventor of the "bikini barista" concept is debated.<ref name="seattimesjan97">{{cite news | url= http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2003535398_coffeegirls22e.html | title= Some coffee stands get steamier | author= Amy Roe | work=[[The Seattle Times]] | date= January 22, 2007 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> The "Natte Latte" chain's first location was opened in November 1999 by Mary Keller, and its employees began sporting pink leather hotpants in 2001.<ref name="hotpants">{{cite news | url= http://www.kitsapsun.com/news/2008/Feb/15/baristas-aim-to-up-coffee-sales-by-stripping/ | title= Baristas Aim to Up Coffee Sales by Stripping Down | author= Chris Henry | work= [[Kitsap Sun]] | date= February 15, 2008 | accessdate= March 9, 2010 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090901053154/http://www.kitsapsun.com/news/2008/feb/15/baristas-aim-to-up-coffee-sales-by-stripping/ | archivedate= September 1, 2009 | df= }}</ref><ref name="hotpants2">{{cite news | url= http://www.seattlepi.com/football/82145_coffee10.shtml | title= Seahawks Stadium hands off coffee contract to Seattle's Best | author= Christine Frey | work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | date= August 12, 2002 | accessdate=March 10, 2010}} ("The first Natte Latte opened in SeaTac in November 1999 and closed two years later, shortly after Keller began working to obtain a contract with the Seahawks, she said. The Gorst location, whose seven employees wear hot pink shorts while preparing coffee, opened in June 2001.")</ref> Next, in 2003, "Cowgirls Espresso" opened its first location in [[Tukwila, Washington]]. A few months after opening, as summer heat invaded the small {{convert|70|sqft|m2|adj=on}} shop, owner Lori Bowden adopted employee suggestions that they start a "Bikini Wednesday" promotion. Sales took off, and other scantily-clad theme days soon followed.<ref name="cbsfeb97">{{cite news | url= http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/02/18/sunday/main2491158.shtml | title= Shedding Clothes And Selling Coffee | author= Caitlin A. Johnson | work=[[CBS News]] | date= February 18, 2007 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="postjan97">{{cite news | url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/29/AR2007012900838.html | title= Seattle-Area Coffee Shops Show Some Skin | author= Gene Johnson ([[Associated Press]]) | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date= January 29, 2007 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref>[[Extreme (Travel Channel series)|Extreme Fast Food]], [[Travel Channel]] segment ("Lori Bowden: 'Cowgirls Espresso was started about seven years ago, about four months after opening, it was about June–July, it was hot. It was a very small espresso stand, 70 square foot. And so they're like, 'what do you think about us wearing a bikini on Wednesday?' And I said, 'hmm, let me check on that.' ... Sales skyrocketed 100%")</ref> The concept of "bikini baristas" spread quickly, featuring attractive young women dressed in attire such as bikinis, lingerie, stockings, and heels.<ref name="postjan97"/><ref name="npr1">{{cite news | url= https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94715155 | title= Bikini Baristas Try To Get Leg Up In Seattle| author= Sara Lerner | work=[[National Public Radio]] | date= September 17, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="girlsok">{{cite news | url= http://www.heraldnet.com/article/20080611/NEWS01/849783084&news01ad=1 | title= Bikini baristas comfortable in their jobs | author= Julie Muhlstein | work=[[The Herald (Everett)]] | date= June 11, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> The first round of international press attention to the trend occurred in early 2007.<ref name="seattimesjan97"/><ref name="postjan97"/><ref name="indy">{{cite news | url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/sexpresso-coffee-shops-take-seattle-by-storm-435093.html | title= Sexpresso coffee shops take Seattle by storm | author= Andrew Gumbel | work=[[The Independent]] | date= February 5, 2007 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> Competitors that have not followed suit have complained about the trend, and have also seen a drop in business.<ref name="complose">{{cite news | url= http://www.heraldnet.com/article/20080516/NEWS01/647107885/0/SPORTS | title='Sexy espresso' stands leave competitors steaming | author= David Chircop | work=[[The Herald (Everett)]] | date= May 16, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref>
The retail establishments which employ bikini baristas often adopt titillating names, including "Peek A-Brew", "Grab n' Go", "Cowgirls Espresso", "Smokin' Hot Espresso",<ref name="cbsphotos">{{cite news | url= http://www.cbsnews.com/2300-504083_162-5990739.html | title= Bikini Barista Controversy Photos| author= | work=[[CBS News]] | date= December 17, 2009 | accessdate=March 9, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100209083404/http://www.cbsnews.com/2300-504083_162-5990739.html| archivedate= 9 February 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> "Knotty Bodies Espresso",<ref name="knotty">{{cite news | url= http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/bellevueblog/2010339374_bikinibaristasstirringthingsupincrossroads.html | title= Bellevue residents blast new bikini espresso stand | author= Nicole Tsong | work=[[The Seattle Times]] | date= November 23, 2009 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> "Java Jigglers",<ref name="getjiggy1">{{cite news | url= http://dailyrecordnews.com/news/article_247c1b26-0db7-57f9-94b3-8635fd6c1578.html | title= Java Jigglers owner arrested on sex charges | author= Chelsea Krotzer | work=Daily Record | date= September 26, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> "Espresso Gone Crazy", "Espresso Gone Wild", "Java Girls",<ref name="npr1"/> "Sweet Spot", "Fantasy Espresso", and "Natte Latte".<ref name="sweetspot">{{cite news | url= http://articles.latimes.com/2007/feb/04/nation/na-sexpresso4 | title= Coffee, with sugar, in Seattle | author= Sam Howe Verhovek | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date= February 4, 2007 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref>
== Controversies and litigation==
The phenomenon of bikini baristas has sometimes caused controversy and complaints from local residents.<ref name="knotty"/><ref name="knotty2">{{cite news | url= http://www.woai.com/news/local/story/Bikini-clad-baristas-serve-up-more-than-a-cupful/q3vbxFORrE6Z7ajit8-lsw.cspx | title= Bikini-clad baristas serve up more than a cupful, it's an eyeful | author= | work= [[KING-TV]] | date= November 24, 2009 | accessdate= March 9, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100203141533/http://www.woai.com/news/local/story/Bikini-clad-baristas-serve-up-more-than-a-cupful/q3vbxFORrE6Z7ajit8-lsw.cspx | archivedate= 2010-02-03 | deadurl= yes | df= }}</ref><ref name="cbsvid">{{cite news | url= http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=5764397n | title= Steamed Over Bikini Baristas (Video) | author= | work=[[CBS News]] | date= November 24, 2009 | accessdate=March 9, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100317130219/http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=5764397n| archivedate= 17 March 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="angels">{{cite news | url= http://www.komonews.com/news/19159479.html | title= Local baristas say bikini, topless trend spilling over | author= | work=[[KOMO-TV]] | date= May 21, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100420052236/http://www.komonews.com/news/19159479.html| archivedate= 20 April 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
As a result of these complaints and incidents, some local jurisdictions have considered adopting local ordinances to regulate and control the activities of the stores.<ref name="coverup">{{cite news | url= http://heraldnet.com/article/20080527/NEWS01/383827930 | title= 'Bikini baristas': Cities explore options for coverup | author= David Chircop | work=[[The Herald (Everett)]] | date= May 27, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="snocoreg">{{cite news | url= http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010463267_apwabikinibaristas.html | title= SnoCo rules bikini baristas are adult businesses | agency= Associated Press | work=[[The Seattle Times]] | date= December 9, 2009 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="evreg">{{cite news | url= http://www.kboi2.com/news/local/63274262.html | title= Washington town sets limits on bikini baristas' behavior | author= Ray Lane | work= [[KBOI-TV]] | date= October 2, 2009 | accessdate= March 9, 2010 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110718232027/http://www.kboi2.com/news/local/63274262.html | archivedate= July 18, 2011 | df= }}</ref>
=== In Snohomish County === Undercover police officers in [[Snohomish County, Washington]], witnessed some baristas performing additional services for extra money, including letting customers touch them, photograph them or watch them lick whipped cream off each other. These statements have been retracted by the Everett WA police department, as the police officer 'undercover' was a known customer and offered money to the barista.<ref name="Did sergeant in 'bikini barista' sting help drive-through coffee shops operate as strip clubs?">{{cite web | url=http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/sergeant_accused_of_helping_bikini_barristas_operate_drive-through_coffee/ | title=Did sergeant in 'bikini barista' sting help drive-through coffee shops operate as strip clubs? | publisher=American Bar Association | date=27 June 2013 | accessdate=31 January 2014 | author=Neil, Martha}}</ref> The Everett, WA police department was accused of [[entrapment]].<ref name="cbs1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldnet.com/article/20090923/NEWS01/909239969/0/FRONTPAGE|title=Five risque Everett Grab-N-Go baristas charged with prostitution|work=The Daily Herald}}</ref> In September 2009, five baristas at a Grab 'n Go in Everett, Washington were charged with [[prostitution]] after police surveillance caught them stripping and performing sexual acts for cash.<ref name="cbsphotos"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://slog.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2010/01/08/your-tax-dollars-hard-at-nsfw|title=Your Tax Dollars Hard at NSFW|work=The Stranger}}</ref> Other complaints were in regard to the stand's proximity to preschools and daycare centers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldnet.com/article/20090207/NEWS01/702079900|title=Racy espresso stand upsets preschool's parents|work=The Daily Herald}}</ref>
In July 2011 the owner and three employees of Java Juggs in [[Edmonds, Washington]], were charged with [[prostitution]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://komonews.com/news/local/java-juggs-baristas-owner-busted-for-prostitution-after-probe-11-21-2015 |title=Java Juggs baristas, owner busted for prostitution after probe |publisher=KOMO News |date= |accessdate=2016-07-21}}</ref> with the police later releasing some footage obtained.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://komonews.com/news/local/undercover-cop-video-shows-barista-stripping-at-coffee-stand-11-21-2015 |title=Undercover cop video shows barista stripping at coffee stand |publisher=KOMO News |date= |accessdate=2016-07-21}}</ref>
[[Everett, Washington|Everett]] (the county seat of and the largest city in Snohomish County), in December 2017 was temporarily enjoined against enforcing a dress code ordinance against bikini baristas by U.S. District Court Judge Marsha Pechman who found it [[unconstitutionally vague]], violated their [[freedom of expression]] and unconstitutional under the [[Equal Protection Clause]] of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|14th Amendment]] since it targeted only women. In 2018 March the city filed an appeal with [[9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals]] and requested the injunction be lifted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldnet.com/news/city-of-everett-files-federal-court-appeal-over-bikini-barista-case/ |title=Rule clear about bikini baristas' exposure, Everett argues |publisher=HearldNet |date= |accessdate=2018-04-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2018/04/03/bikini-baristas-hit-with-court-brief-demanding-cover-up.html/ |title=Bikini baristas hit with court brief demanding they cover up |publisher=FOXNews |date= |accessdate=2018-04-03}}</ref>
=== In Belfair, Washington === In another incident, "Espresso Gone Wild" in [[Belfair, Washington]] was temporarily shut down by [[Mason County, Washington|Mason County]] in August 2008. It drew the ire of Belfair residents. Mason County officials responded to complaints on the July 30, 2008 meeting by ruling the espresso stand is "erotic entertainment" and off limits in the Belfair area. The owners of "Espresso Gone Wild" in Belfair were being told that their baristas are violating an erotic entertainment ordinance. They were also told that their baristas need to cover up and clean up their act or the stand will be shut down permanently. Mason County Commissioner [[Tim Sheldon]] says the owners of "Espresso Gone Wild" are welcome to open a coffee shop and compete with all the other coffee shops in town. Sheldon also says the owners won't be able to sell sex and coffee on the side.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.king5.com/archive/60433417.html |title=Belfair cracks down on sexpresso stands | KING5.com Seattle |publisher=King5.com |date=2008-08-04 |accessdate=2013-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203020334/http://www.king5.com/archive/60433417.html |archivedate=2014-02-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kirotv.com/videos/news/video-one-county-says-no-bikini-baristas-another/vCfZk/ |title=VIDEO: One County Says No Bikini Baristas, Another Says OK |publisher=KiroTV |date=2013-07-24 |accessdate=2013-07-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201201246/http://www.kirotv.com/videos/news/video-one-county-says-no-bikini-baristas-another/vCfZk/ |archivedate=2014-02-01 |df= }}</ref> "Espresso Gone Wild" in [[Belfair, Washington]] was prohibited from allowing employees to wear [[pasties]] and their baristas now wear bikinis.<ref name="npr1"/> Residents in another community have surveilled a local stand and called for [[boycott]]s of companies whose employees patronize the establishments.<ref name="bigbro">{{cite news | url= http://www.kirotv.com/news/21599815/detail.html | title= Tattler Web Site Outs Workers Seen Visiting Bare Baristas | author= | work= [[KIRO-TV]] | date= November 12, 2009 | accessdate= March 9, 2010 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100119015557/http://www.kirotv.com/news/21599815/detail.html | archivedate= 2010-01-19 | deadurl= yes | df= }}</ref>
=== In Yakima, Washington === In Yakima, Washington, a bikini bar owner was sentenced to 100 hours of community service and fined $1,000<ref name="Coffee Shop Owner Guilty of Indecent Exposure Due to Skimpy See-Through Shorts on 'Bikini Barista'">{{cite web | url=http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/coffee_shop_owner_guilty_of_indecent_explosure_due_to_skimpy/ | title=Coffee Shop Owner Guilty of Indecent Exposure Due to Skimpy See-Through Shorts on 'Bikini Barista' | publisher=American Bar Association | date=7 February 2011 | accessdate=31 January 2014 | author=Neil, Martha}}</ref> because, at the coffee shop, the barista "wore shorts determined to be both too skimpy and too sheer. A city ordinance bans bikini baristas from wearing G-strings and see-through clothing."<ref name="Do coffee baristas serve up too much while wearing too little? Cities enact new laws, conduct raids">{{cite web | url=http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/some_like_it_hot_proclaims_racy_coffee_kiosk_but_some_area_residents_do_not/ | title=Do coffee baristas serve up too much while wearing too little? Cities enact new laws, conduct raids | publisher=American Bar Association | date=28 January 2014 | accessdate=31 January 2014 | author=Neil, Martha}}</ref> The barista was charged but acquitted by the jury in the indecent exposure case.<ref name="Coffee Shop Owner Guilty of Indecent Exposure Due to Skimpy See-Through Shorts on 'Bikini Barista'"/>
== Growth outside Seattle area == [[File:Bikini Coffee (Hillsboro, Oregon).jpg|right|thumb|A bikini barista coffee kiosk in Hillsboro, Oregon]]
Some entrepreneurs have opened bikini barista stores with success outside the Seattle area, including in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]],<ref>{{cite news | url= http://www.newsobserver.com/2013/01/06/2587071/shaffer-coffee-with-a-sexy-smile.html | author= Josh Shaffer | date= January 6, 2013 | accessdate= January 8, 2013 | title= Shaffer: Coffee with a sexy smile at Cup O Jane | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130108215622/http://www.newsobserver.com/2013/01/06/2587071/shaffer-coffee-with-a-sexy-smile.html | archivedate= January 8, 2013 | df= }}</ref> [[Aurora, Colorado]],<ref name="aurora1">{{cite news | url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jXvEgHI0wtM8mgYkNOgWamA4CE1AD9G5GQ5G0 | title= Bikini coffee shop sparks boycott in Colo. | agency=[[Associated Press]] | date= June 6, 2010 | accessdate=June 10, 2010}}(describing boycott called for "Perky Cups" in Aurora, Colorado)</ref> [[Portland, Oregon]],<ref name="portland1">{{cite news | url= http://www.oregonlive.com/news/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/news/1214358965169540.xml&coll=7 | title= Bikini Coffee tries Portland on for size | author= Helen Jung | work=[[The Oregonian]] | date= June 25, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> [[Youngstown, Ohio]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vindy.com/news/2012/jul/14/boardman-take-break-oking-vendors/ |title=Youngstown News, Boardman to take a break from OK'ing vendors |publisher=[[Vindy.com]] |date=2012-07-14 |accessdate=2013-07-29}}</ref> [[Tampa, Florida]],<ref name="tampa">{{cite news | url= http://carrollwood2.tbo.com/content/2008/mar/26/cw-babes-in-the-hood/ | title= Babes In The 'Hood | author= Harold Valentine | work= [[The Tampa Tribune]] | date= March 26, 2008 | accessdate= March 9, 2010 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081102221859/http://carrollwood2.tbo.com/content/2008/mar/26/cw-babes-in-the-hood/ | archivedate= November 2, 2008 | df= }}</ref> [[Pasadena, Maryland]],<ref>{{cite news | url= http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/midnight_sun/blog/2010/08/java_divas_has_bikini_baristas.html | title= Java Divas has baristas in bikinis (and other outfits) | author= Sam Sessa | work=[[Baltimore Sun]] | date= August 2, 2010 | accessdate=August 2, 2010}}</ref> [[Chatsworth, Georgia]],<ref name="georgia">{{cite news | url= http://daltondailycitizen.com/local/x1048545895/Bikini-themed-coffee-shop-opens-in-Chatsworth | title= Bikini-themed coffee shop opens in Chatsworth | author= Mark Millican | work=[[The Daily Citizen (Dalton)]] | date= July 14, 2009 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]],<ref name="vegas1">{{cite news | url= http://www.firstcoastnews.com/news/strange/news-article.aspx?storyid=95299 | title= Sexpresso: Coffee with a Sexy Twist | author= Gary Dettman | work=[[KVBC-DT]] | date= November 18, 2007 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="vegas2">{{cite news | url= http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-11331034.html | title= Some like it hottie at new Vegas coffee shop | author= | work=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] | date= November 27, 2007 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> [[Texas]], and [[Missouri]].<ref name="texas1">{{cite news | url= http://www.brownsvilleherald.com/articles/coffee-86703-girls-java.html | title= Barista Beauties: Coffee shop to feature sexy servers | author= | work=[[The Brownsville Herald]] | date= May 18, 2008 | accessdate=March 10, 2010}}</ref><ref name="mizzou1">{{cite news | url= http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=11EADF26DBB016C8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | title= Hot coffee shop is far cooler than its racy reputation | author= Susan Weich | work=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] | date= May 18, 2008 | accessdate=March 10, 2010}}</ref> ''Baristas'' has been dubbed the [[Hooters]] of coffee due to its size and popularity in the market.<ref>{{cite web |title=Hooters of coffee coming to Cape Coral |work=[[The News-Press|News-Press]] |publisher=FLNewsFeed |date=2013-06-21 |url=http://www.news-press.com/article/20130621/BUSINESS/306210024/Hooters-of-coffee-coming-to-Cape-Coral?nclick_check=1 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102125438/http://www.flnewsfeed.com/cape-coral/hooters-of-coffee-coming-to-cape-coral/ |archivedate=2013-11-02 |accessdate=2014-05-09}}</ref> Hooters is place in which scantily clad women serve food and drinks to patrons. Bikini Beans is another such place in the US.<ref>http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/news/bikini-beans-coming-to-tempe-sparks-social-media-backlash-against-city-councilman-7820638</ref>
A Los Angeles area store called "Bikini Espresso" only lasted four months in the Los Angeles area in 2009, and closed with complaints of over-regulation.<ref name="torrance">{{cite news | url= http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/weird/Bikini-Clad-Baristas-69327182.html | title= Bye Bye, Bikini Baristas | author= Jenna Briand | work=[[KNBC]] | date= November 5, 2009 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref>
One chain in particular called "Bottoms Up Espresso",<ref name="kcra">{{cite news | url= http://www.kcra.com/Skin-Is-In-At-Modesto-Coffee-Shops/-/11798090/12656746/-/15r356t/-/index.html | title= Skin Is In At Modesto Coffee Shops | author= Staff | publisher= KCRA Channel 3 | date= Jul 29, 2011 | accessdate= October 10, 2013 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131203051138/http://www.kcra.com/Skin-Is-In-At-Modesto-Coffee-Shops/-/11798090/12656746/-/15r356t/-/index.html | archivedate= December 3, 2013 | df= }}</ref> who have expanded into multiple Northern California markets including locations in [[Modesto, California]];<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.modbee.com/2011/08/03/1801988/bikini-clad-baristas-in-modesto.html |title=Local and Breaking News from The Modesto Bee in Modesto, California |publisher=ModBee.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202222323/http://www.modbee.com/2011/08/03/1801988/bikini-clad-baristas-in-modesto.html |archivedate=2013-12-02 |df= }}</ref> [[Tracy, California]]; [[Clovis, California]]; [[Bakersfield, California]]; and Vernalis, California; has quickly become a favorite among social media users with their baristas featured regularly on the website [[The Chive]]<ref name="chive">{{cite news | url= http://thechive.com/2013/10/03/so-you-pull-up-to-the-drive-thru-at-bottoms-up-espresso-and-then-amber-18-photos/ | title= So you pull up to the drive thru at Bottoms Up Espresso and then Amber | author= John | work=The Chive | date= October 3, 2011 | accessdate=October 10, 2013}}</ref> and other popular websites. With the brands growing popularity they have expanded into a mobile food truck style service and expanded into its own line of merchandise including yearly calendars featuring their current line up of bikini baristas.<ref name="juggalonews">{{cite news | url= http://www.juggalonews.com/home/index.php/content/stuff/1952-mars-top-places-to-eat | title= Mars' Top 15 Places To Dine In Northern California | work= Juggalo News | date= September 21, 2013 | accessdate= October 10, 2013 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225530/http://www.juggalonews.com/home/index.php/content/stuff/1952-mars-top-places-to-eat | archivedate= December 2, 2013 | df= }}</ref>
[[File:Pink Pantherz.jpg|thumb|A Pink Pantherz kiosk in [[Fremont, California]]]]
Two bikini barista businesses are opened in northwest [[Fresno, California]], Java Girls Espresso and Pink Pantherz Espresso, since the summer of 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Clough|first1=Bethany|title=Bikini baristas now serving coffee in Fresno shops|url=http://www.fresnobee.com/2014/06/17/3982634/bikini-baristas-have-come-to-fresno.html|accessdate=June 17, 2014|work=The Fresno Bee|date=June 17, 2014}}</ref> However, on Facebook, Java Girls Espresso's owner Terry Ford announced that it closed its door on January 1, 2015 due to financial difficulty.
== Outside the United States == *Laura Maggi, a woman in her mid 30s, became a national celebrity in Italy in 2012 as a result of starting a habit of coming to work in revealing attire at the coffee bar called Le Cafe that she owns and operates in the small Italian town of Bagnolo Mella. She continues to generate local controversy serving "sexpresso" as she wears a variety of revealing outfits when serving customers. She also has female assistants who do the same, and sells glamour calendars of herself in addition to the coffee. Maggi has been the subject of photo-illustrated articles in popular tabloids, such as the ''Daily Mail'' in the United Kingdom and ''Oggi'' in Italy.<ref name="Daily Mail">{{cite news | url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2105339/Laura-Maggi-Le-Cafe-Busty-barmaid-serves-drinks-skimpy-outfits.html | title= Sexpresso: Wives ban their husbands from visiting Italian cafe where busty barmaid serves up drinks in skimpy outfits | author= Nick Pisa | work=[[Daily Mail]] | date= 25 February 2012 | accessdate= August 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Oggi">{{cite news | url= http://www.oggi.it/gossip/gossip/2014/02/28/laura-maggi-business-a-gogo-le-foto-sexy-pure/#anchor-comments | title= Laura Maggi, business a gogò. Le foto sexy pure | author= none | work=[[Oggi]] | date= 28 February 2014 | accessdate= August 25, 2015}}</ref> *A phenomenon similar to bikini baristas is very popular in [[Chile]], known as "[[café con piernas]]" (literally, coffee with legs) and existed long before their Seattle counterpart.<ref name="npr2">{{cite news | url= https://www.npr.org/blogs/daydreaming/2008/09/a_little_skin_with_your_latte_1.html | title= A Little Skin With Your Latte? | author= Heather Murphy | publisher=[[National Public Radio]] | date= September 17, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="santtimes">{{cite news | url= http://www.santiagotimes.cl/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=14337:CAF%C3%89-CON-PIERNAS:-GOOD-%27TIL-THE-LAST-DROP&catid=68:revolver-weekend-edition&Itemid=145 | title= CAFÉ CON PIERNAS: GOOD 'TIL THE LAST DROP | author= Adam Fuller and Jason Snyder | work=[[The Santiago Times]] | date= August 1, 2008 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref><ref name="sfchron">{{cite news | url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2006/02/12/TRGQ1H3M241.TMP | title= Out on a limb for coffee with legs | author= John Flinn | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date= February 12, 2006 | accessdate=March 9, 2010}}</ref> *In Taiwan, young women who sell betel nuts and cigarettes from brightly lit glass enclosures while wearing revealing clothing are called [[Betel nut beauty|Betel nut beauties]]. They debuted in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/editorials/archives/2007/03/12/2003351976 |last=Huang |first=Wan-tran |title=Why Pick on Betel-nut Beauties? |work=Taipei Times |date=12 March 2007 |accessdate=13 November 2012}}</ref> *In Japan, "[[no-pan kissa]]" (no-panty coffee shop) blossomed in the 80s, where the waitresses have short skirts and no panties. Typical of Japanese sex-fads, they didn't last more than a few years before they morphed into other (but similar) businesses. *In [[Surfers Paradise, Queensland]], gold lamé [[Surfers Paradise Meter Maids|bikini-clad meter maids]] stroll up and down the beach feeding coins into parking meters so that beach-goers won't get parking tickets. Though feeding meters is illegal in Surfers Paradise, local law enforcement is encouraged to look the other way, as the Meter Maids not only keep tourists happy, but they have also become a tourist attraction themselves.<ref name=clock>{{cite news|last1=Marks|first1=Kathy|title=Clock is ticking for Australia's bikini-clad Meter Maids|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/australasia/clock-is-ticking-for-australias-bikiniclad-meter-maids-1972212.html|accessdate=2015-04-27|work=The Independent (UK)|date=2010-05-13}}</ref>
==Sex work== In a column published in ''[[Sociological Images]]'', the sociologist [[Lisa Wade]] has used the bikini barista as a launching point for a discussion of the boundaries of [[sex work]].<ref>{{citation|title=Are bikini baristas sex workers? Are you? |author=Lisa Wade, PhD|authorlink=Lisa Wade |date=August 18, 2015|website=[[Sociological Images]]|url=https://thesocietypages.org/socimages/2015/08/18/are-bikini-baristas-sex-workers-are-you/}}</ref> The question has also been the subject of an essay published in ''[[The Atlantic]]''.<ref>{{citation|title='Just Because I Work Here Doesn't Mean I Don't Respect Myself'. Bikini-clad baristas serve up coffee at several drive-through stands in Washington. Locals and city councils can't decide: Are they sex workers?|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=April 7, 2015|author=Leah SOTTILE |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2015/04/just-because-i-work-here-doesnt-mean-i-dont-respect-myself/389760/}}</ref>
== See also == {{portal|Coffee}} * [[Breastaurant]] * [[Café con piernas]] in Chile, preceded the Pacific Northwest phenomenon * [[Hooters]]

{{DEFAULTSORT:Bikini Barista}} [[Category:Baristas]] [[Category:Bikinis]] [[Category:Coffee culture]] [[Category:Coffee in Seattle]] [[Category:Culture of Seattle]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Snohomish County, Washington]] [[Category:Gendered occupations]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Brahui
براہوئی, Baloch |image = [[File:Brahui people of Quetta.jpg |250px]] |caption = A photograph from 1910 with the caption reading "Brahui of [[Quetta]]" |langs = [[Brahui language|Brahui]]
[[Balochi language|Balochi]] |rels = [[Sunni Islam]] ([[Hanafi]]) |related = [[Baloch people|Balochis]]}} {{Dravidian}} The '''Brahui''' ([[Brahui language|Brahui]]: براہوئی,) or '''Brahvi''' people are an ethnic group of about 2.2 million people with the vast majority found in [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Baluchistan]], [[Pakistan]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Sundayapp/lWCoIZ2K5dPycrhS1gk6nJ/A-slice-of-south-India-in-Balochistan.html|title=A slice of south India in Balochistan|last=Venkatesh|first=Karthik|date=2017-02-18|work=livemint.com/|access-date=2017-12-27}} They are a small minority group in [[Afghanistan]], where they are native, but they are also found through their diaspora in [[Middle East]]ern states.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fOQkpcVcd9AC&pg=PT73|title=Brahuis|work=Ethnic Groups of South Asia and the Pacific: An Encyclopedia|author=James B. Minahan|accessdate=21 November 2015}} They mainly occupy the area in Balochistan from [[Bolan Pass]] through the Bolan Hills to Ras Muari ([[Cape Monze]]) on the Arabian sea, separating the [[Baloch people]] of [[Balochistan]] to the west and the [[Sindhi people]] of [[Sindh]] in the east. The Brahuis are almost entirely [[Sunni]] [[Muslim]]s.{{cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CnckpL8auSIC&pg=PA96&dq=brahui+hindu#v=onepage&q=brahui%20hindu&f=false| title = Dictionary of Languages: The Definitive Reference to More Than 400 Languages|publisher = Columbia University Press|accessdate = 2010-09-09|isbn = 9780231115698|date = 2004-03-01}} There is a varied pattern of language use among the Brahui: some of the constituent groups predominantly speak the Dravidian [[Brahui language]], others are bilingual in [[Balochi language|Balochi]] and Brahui, while others are speakers only of Balochi. ==Origins== The fact that other Dravidian languages only exist further south in India has led to several speculations about the origins of the Brahui. There are three hypotheses regarding the Brahui that have been proposed by academics. One theory is that the Brahui are a [[relict population]] of Dravidians, surrounded by speakers of [[Indo-Iranian languages]], remaining from a time when Dravidian was more widespread. A second theory is that they migrated to [[Baluchistan]] from [[Mainland India|inner India]] during the early Muslim period of the 13th or 14th centuries.[Sergent, ''Genèse de l'Inde''] The third theory says the Brahui migrated to Balochistan from [[Central India]] after 1000 AD. The absence of any older Iranian (Avestan) influence in Brahui supports this last hypothesis. The main Iranian contributor to Brahui vocabulary is a northwestern Iranian language, [[Balochi language|Baluchi]], [[Sindhi language|Sindhi]] and southeastern [[Iranian language]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]].{{cite journal | last1 = Elfenbein | first1 = J. H. | year = 1987 | title = A periplous of the 'Brahui problem' | url = | journal = Studia Iranica | volume = 16 | issue = | pages = 215–233 | doi=10.2143/si.16.2.2014604}} However, the Brahui do not have higher genetic affinity with Dravidian populations in India than other neighboring Indo-Iranian Pakistanis. Pagani, et al., conclude that this shows that the Brahui, although speaking a Dravidian language, had their Dravidian genetic component completely replaced by Indo-Iranian speakers, suggesting that the Brahui are descendents of a previous relict population whose genomes were replaced when more recent Indo-Iranian speakers arrived in South Asia.{{Cite journal|last=Pagani|first=Luca|last2=Colonna|first2=Vincenza|last3=Tyler-Smith|first3=Chris|last4=Ayub|first4=Qasim|date=2017|title=An Ethnolinguistic and Genetic Perspective on the Origins of the Dravidian-Speaking Brahui in Pakistan|journal=Man in India|volume=97|issue=1|pages=267–278|issn=0025-1569|pmc=5378296|pmid=28381901}} Linguistic findings and oral histories of the Brahui however say otherwise.Pagani (2017) states in its "Conclusion" that there is "No historical or linguistic data support" the possibility that "the Brahui ancestors were Indo-European speakers, who later adopted a Dravidian language."{{cite journal | last1 = Elfenbein | first1 = Josef | year = 1987 | title = A periplus of the 'Brahui problem' | url = | journal = Studia Iranica | volume = 16 | issue = 2| pages = 215–233 | doi = 10.2143/SI.16.2.2014604 }}PP. 27, 142, Krishnamurti, Bhadriraju (2003), The Dravidian Languages, Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|0-521-77111-0}}.P. 12 Origin and Spread of the Tamils By V. R. Ramachandra DikshitarP. 32 Ideology and status of Sanskrit : contributions to the history of the Sanskrit language by Jan E M Houben {{Quotation|The history of the Brahui emerges from total darkness with the displacement of a shadowy Hindu dynasty in [[Kalat, Pakistan|Kalat]] called Sewa by the [[Mirwani]] Brahuis. There is a [[Mughal (tribe)|Mughal]] interlude and then Brahui ascendancy again.Language and linguistic area: essays By Murray Barnson Emeneau, Selected and introduced by Anwar S. Dil, Stanford University Press. Page 334|sign=Murray Barnson Emeneau|source=Language and Linguistic Area: page 334}} {{Quotation|It is said that a [[Hindu]] dynasty, the [[Sewa Dynasty|Sewa]] by name, ruled over this part of the country prior to the seventh century, Kalat is still known as Kalat-i-Sewa.Population Census Organisation, Statistics Division, Govt. of Pakistan, 1999, 1998 district census report of Kalat Page 7.}} ==Tribes== There are three groups of Brahui tribes. The "nucleus" consists of the Achmadzai, Gurguari, Iltazai, Kalandari, [[Kambrani]], Mirwari, Rodeni and the Sumalari, which altogether account for only a small proportion of the total number of Brahuis. The majority of the population is divided up between the Jhalawan Brahuis (which include the tribes of the Bizanjars, Harunis, [[Muhammad Hasni]]s, [[Mengal]]s, Siapad, Nicharis, Pandranis, Sajdis and the Zahris), and the Sarawan Brahuis (comprising the tribes of the [[Muhammad Shahi]], [[Bangulzai tribe|Bangulzai]], [[Kūrd]], [[Lehri tribe|Lahri]], [[Langov]], [[Raisani]], Rustamzai, Sarparah, Satakzai, Shahwani and Zagar-Mengal).{{sfn|Scholz|2002|p=28}} ==Language== {{Main|Brahui language}} The Brahui language is a Dravidian language, even though it is very far from South India. It is mainly spoken in the Kalat areas of [[Balochistan (Pakistan)|Balochistan]], Pakistan, and in Southern Afghanistan, as well as by an unknown very small number of expatriates in the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Persian Gulf states]], [[Turkmenistan]], as well as Iranian [[Balochistan (Iran)|Balochistan]].https://books.google.com/books?id=bCkaAQAAIAAJ It has three dialects: Sarawani (spoken in the north), Jhalawani (spoken in the southeast), and Chaghi (spoken in the northwest and west) The 2013 edition of Ethnologue reports that there are some 4.2 million speakers; 4 million live in Pakistan, mainly in the province of Balochistan. Due to its isolation, Brahui's vocabulary is only 15% Dravidian, while the remainder is dominated by [[Balochi language|Balochi]], and [[Indo-Aryan languages]] (for example, of the number names from "one" to "ten," "four" through "ten" are borrowed from Persian). Brahui is generally written in the [[Perso-Arabic script]] and there is even a [[Latin script|Latin alphabet]] that has been developed for use with Brahui. ===Dialects=== Kalat, Jhalawan, and Sarawan, with Kalat as the standard dialect. At present Brahui is spoken in [[Pakistani Balochistan]], Afghanistan, [[Turkmenistan]], [[Sindh]] and the Persian Gulf [[Arab]] states. ==Genetics== Brahuis display a variety of [[Human Y-chromosome DNA haplogroup|Y-DNA]] [[haplogroups]], the most important being haplogroup [[Haplogroup R1a (Y-DNA)|R1a1a-M17]](35% to 39.09%) - with its mass diffusion among populations of [[Central Asia|Central]]/[[South Asia]] and associated with the early eastern migrations of [[Indo-Iranians|Indo-Iranian]] nomads.{{cite journal|title=Separating the post-Glacial coancestry of European and Asian Y chromosomes within haplogroup R1a| pmc=2987245 | pmid=19888303 | doi=10.1038/ejhg.2009.194| volume=18| year=2010| journal=Eur. J. Hum. Genet.| pages=479–84 | last1 = Underhill | first1 = PA | last2 = Myres | first2 = NM | last3 = Rootsi | first3 = S | last4 = Metspalu | first4 = M | last5 = Zhivotovsky | first5 = LA | last6 = King | first6 = RJ | last7 = Lin | first7 = AA | last8 = Chow | first8 = CE | last9 = Semino | first9 = O | last10 = Battaglia | first10 = V | last11 = Kutuev | first11 = I | last12 = Järve | first12 = M | last13 = Chaubey | first13 = G | last14 = Ayub | first14 = Q | last15 = Mohyuddin | first15 = A | last16 = Mehdi | first16 = SQ | last17 = Sengupta | first17 = S | last18 = Rogaev | first18 = EI | last19 = Khusnutdinova | first19 = EK | last20 = Pshenichnov | first20 = A | last21 = Balanovsky | first21 = O | last22 = Balanovska | first22 = E | last23 = Jeran | first23 = N | last24 = Augustin | first24 = DH | last25 = Baldovic | first25 = M | last26 = Herrera | first26 = RJ | last27 = Thangaraj | first27 = K | last28 = Singh | first28 = V | last29 = Singh | first29 = L | last30 = Majumder | first30 = P | last31 = Rudan | first31 = P | last32 = Primorac | first32 = D | last33 = Villems | first33 = R | last34 = Kivisild | first34 = T}}{{cite journal|title=Y-Chromosomal DNA Variation in Pakistan| pmc=447589 | pmid=11898125 | doi=10.1086/339929| volume=70| date=May 2002| journal=Am. J. Hum. Genet.| pages=1107–24 | last1 = Qamar | first1 = R | last2 = Ayub | first2 = Q | last3 = Mohyuddin | first3 = A | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al}} Haplogroup [[Haplogroup J (Y-DNA)|J]], which is found among other [[South Asia|subcontinental]] peoples and more typical of Near-Eastern populations occurs at 28%.{{cite journal|title=Polarity and Temporality of High-Resolution Y-Chromosome Distributions in India Identify Both Indigenous and Exogenous Expansions and Reveal Minor Genetic Influence of Central Asian Pastoralists| pmc=1380230 | pmid=16400607 | doi=10.1086/499411| volume=78| date=February 2006| journal=Am. J. Hum. Genet.| pages=202–21 | last1 = Sengupta | first1 = S | last2 = Zhivotovsky | first2 = LA | last3 = King | first3 = R | display-authors = 3 | last4 = et al}} Other, relatively minor, low-frequency haplogroups among the Brahui are those of [[Haplogroup G (Y-DNA)|G]], [[haplogroup L (Y-DNA)|L]], [[Haplogroup E1b1a (Y-DNA)|E1b1a]], and [[Haplogroup N (Y-DNA)|N]]. These haplogroups show that the Brahui population genetics are largely indistinguishable from those of Indo-Iranian speakers which are adjacent to them, like the Balochi and Makrani, but different from those further away, such as Sindhi. According to Quintana-Murci et al. (2004), the Brahui population has a high prevalence (55%) of western Eurasian mtDNAs and the lowest frequency in the region (21%) of [[Haplogroup M (mtDNA)|haplogroup M]]*, which is common (∼60%) among the Dravidian-speaking Indians. So the possibility of the Dravidian presence in Baluchistan originating from recent entry of Dravidians of India should be excluded. It also shows their maternal gene pool is similar to Indo-Iranian speakers. The present Brahui population may have originated from ancient Indian Dravidian-speakers who may have relocated to Baluchistan and admixed with locals; however, no historical record supports this. So it is suggested that they are the last northern survivors of a larger Dravidian-speaking region before Indo-Iranian arrived. This would, if true, reinforce the proto-Elamo-Dravidian hypothesis.{{Cite journal|last=Quintana-Murci|first=Lluís|last2=Chaix|first2=Raphaëlle|last3=Wells|first3=R. Spencer|last4=Behar|first4=Doron M.|last5=Sayar|first5=Hamid|last6=Scozzari|first6=Rosaria|last7=Rengo|first7=Chiara|last8=Al-Zahery|first8=Nadia|last9=Semino|first9=Ornella|date=2004-05|title=Where West Meets East: The Complex mtDNA Landscape of the Southwest and Central Asian Corridor|url=https://www.cell.com/ajhg/fulltext/S0002-9297(07)64352-3?code=ajhg-site|journal=The American Journal of Human Genetics|language=English|volume=74|issue=5|pages=827–845|doi=10.1086/383236|issn=0002-9297}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== *{{Cite book| last = Scholz| first = Fred| title = Nomadism & colonialism : a hundred years of Baluchistan, 1872-1972| date = 2002| orig-year = 1974| location = Karachi ; Oxford ; New York|publisher = Oxford University Press| isbn = 978-0-19-579638-4| ref = harv}} *{{cite journal |last1=Qamar|first1=Raheel|last2=Ayub|first2=Qasim|last3=Mohyuddin|first3=Aisha|last4=Helgason|first4=Agnar|last5=Kehkashan|first5=Mazhar|last6=Atika|first6=Mansoor|last7=Zerjal|first7=Tatjana|last8=Tyler-Smith|first8=Chris|last9=Mehdi|first9=S. Qasim |title=Y-Chromosomal DNA Variation in Pakistan|journal=American Journal of Human Genetics |date=2002-03-15|volume=70|issue=5|pages=1107–1124|doi=10.1086/339929|pmid=11898125 |pmc=447589}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Brahui}} {{EB1911 poster|Brahui}} *[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/brahui Brahui people] at Encyclopædia Iranica {{Ethnic groups in Afghanistan}} {{Ethnic groups in Pakistan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brahui People}} [[Category:Brahui people|*]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Afghanistan]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Pakistan]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of South Asia]] [[Category:Social groups of Balochistan, Pakistan]] [[Category:Dravidian peoples|*]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox language |name=Cao Miao |nativename= |states=[[China]] |region=[[Guizhou]], [[Hunan]], [[Guangxi]] |speakers={{sigfig|63,600|2}} |date=2000 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Kradai |fam1=[[Kra–Dai languages|Kra–Dai]] |fam2=[[Kam–Sui languages|Kam–Sui]] |fam3=[[Kam language|Kam]] |iso3=cov |glotto=caom1238 |glottorefname=Cao Miao |notice= }}
'''Cao Miao''' ({{zh|草苗}}; autonym: ''{{IPA|mjiu˥ɲaŋ˧}}''<ref>Shi (2015:1)</ref>) is a variety of Dong ([[Kam language|Kam]]) according to Shi Lin (2012).<ref name="ShiLin2012">Shi Lin [石林] (2012). ''[http://wuxizazhi.cnki.net/Search/MZYW201204012.htm The Cao Miao language of three provinces and its relationship to Dong]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}'' [三省坡草苗的语言及其与侗语的关系]. In ''Minzu Yuwen'' [民族语文] 2012, no. 4. Beijing: China Social Sciences Academy [中国社会科学院].</ref> Dialects include Liushi ("Sixty") Miao 六十苗, Sishi ("Forty") Miao 四十苗, and Ershi ("Twenty") Miao 二十苗 (also known as Flowery Miao 花苗). The Flowery Miao 花苗 do not consider themselves to be Cao Miao 草苗, although their language is similar to Sixty Miao and Forty Miao (Shi 2012).
==Subdivisions== There are various ethnic subgroups within Cao Miao (Shi 2015:7).
*'''Inner Miao 内部苗''' (or 内岗苗 / 内堺苗) (''kaŋ42 kau31''): 2 subgroups **'''Sixty (60) Miao 六十苗''' (''mjiu55 ljok22 ɕəp22''<ref name="Shi p.42">Shi (2015:42)</ref>) **'''Forty (40) Miao 四十苗''' (''mjiu55 si53 ɕəp22''<ref name="Shi p.42"/>), also called '''Diao 刁族''' (''tjau13'')<ref>Shi (2015:43)</ref> *'''Middle Miao 中部苗''' (or 中岗苗 / 中堺苗) (''kaŋ42 ta53''), also called '''Twenty (20) Miao 二十苗''' (''mjiu55 ȵi33 ɕəp22''<ref name="Shi p.42"/>) or '''Flowery Miao 花苗''' (''mjiu55 ken53''<ref name="Shi p.42"/>). *'''Outer Miao 外部苗''' (or 外岗苗 / 外堺苗) (''kaŋ42 pak33''), also called '''Old Miao 老苗''' or '''Black Miao 黑苗'''.
Other ethnolinguistic groups living near the Cao Miao include the Han 汉族, Dong 侗族, Yao 瑶族, Suantang 酸汤人, [[Sanqiao language|Sanqiao]] 三撬人,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.docin.com/p-361267415.html |title=三锹人与清水江中下游的山地开发——以黔东南锦屏县岑梧村为中心的考察 - 豆丁网 |language=zh |website=Docin.com |date=2012-03-13 |accessdate=2016-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304051940/http://www.docin.com/p-361267415.html |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref> [[Tongdao Pinghua|Pinghua]] speakers, [[Hakka Chinese|Hakka]] 客家人, Chuanmin 船民 (a Guibei 桂北 [[Yue Chinese]] lect<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cllc.gxnu.edu.cn/wenzixue/uploadfiles/baiyun/%E6%A1%82%E5%8D%97%E7%96%8D%E5%AE%B6%E8%AF%9D%E7%9A%84%E5%BD%92%E5%B1%9E.pdf |format=PDF |title=桂南置家话的归属 ‘ |website=Cllc.gxnu.edu.cn |accessdate=2016-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304085729/http://www.cllc.gxnu.edu.cn/wenzixue/uploadfiles/baiyun/%E6%A1%82%E5%8D%97%E7%96%8D%E5%AE%B6%E8%AF%9D%E7%9A%84%E5%BD%92%E5%B1%9E.pdf |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref>), [[Naxi Yao language|Naxi]] 那溪人, Liujia 六甲人,<ref>{{cite web|author=Hou Jingrong [侯井榕]|date=2009|title=Phonological System and Linguistic Typology of Liujia Chinese Dialect in Sanjiang of Guangxi Autonomous Region [广西三江县六甲话的语言特点]|url=http://comonca.org.cn/PDF/2009/COMONCA03-010.pdf|format=PDF|website=Comonca.org|accessdate=2016-02-11}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and Liuse 六色人.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnki.com.cn/Article/CJFDTotal-GZMZ201301021.htm |title=三省坡草苗的语言及其系属调查研究-《贵州民族大学学报(哲学社会科学版)》2013年01期 |website=Cnki.com.cn |date= |accessdate=2016-02-11}}</ref>
==Population== There is a total of 58,900 Cao Miao people (Shi 2015:9). The following population statistics are from Shi (2015:9).
By ethnic subgroup: *60 Miao: 49,300 people (in 126 villages<ref>Shi (2015:8)</ref>) *20 Miao (Flowery Miao): 5,930 people *40 Miao (also called Diao 刁族): 3,620 people (in 18 villages of Liping and Tongdao counties<ref>Shi (2015:44)</ref>)
By county: *[[Liping County]], [[Guizhou]]: 19,000 people (consisting of 60 Miao, 40 Miao, and 20 Miao) *[[Sanjiang Dong Autonomous County]], [[Guangxi]]: 31,600 people (consisting of only 60 Miao) *[[Tongdao Dong Autonomous County]], [[Hunan]]: 6,800 people (consisting of 60 Miao and 20 Miao, but no 40 Miao) *[[Congjiang County]], [[Guizhou]]: 1,020 people (consisting of only 40 Miao) *[[Jingzhou]], [[Hunan]]: 500+ people (consisting of 20 Miao and Outer Miao)
==Distribution== Below are languages and their respective locations studied by Shi Lin (2012).<ref name="ShiLin2012"/> *''Liushi (60) Miao'' 六十苗: Qifan 起凡 (in Liping), Dagaoping 大高坪 (in Tongdao), Gaoyu 高宇 (in Sanjiang) *''Sishi (40) Miao'' 四十苗: Tanghua 堂华 (in Tongdao) *''Ershi (20) Miao'' 二十苗: Kenxi 肯溪 (in Tongdao) *''Southern Dong'': Longcheng 陇城 (in Tongdao), Chengyang 程阳 (in Sanjiang) *''Northern Dong'': Xiudong 秀洞 (in Jinping), Sanmentang 三门塘 (in Tianzhu)
Ethnic Cao Miao also live in the following townships.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caomiao.net/cz/ |title=草苗/草苗之窗/草苗论坛 |website=Caomiao.net |date= |accessdate=2016-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130825181606/http://www.caomiao.net/cz/ |archivedate=2013-08-25 |df= }}</ref> *[[Sanjiang Dong Autonomous County]], [[Guangxi]] **Tongle 同乐乡 **Bajiang 八江乡 **Liangkou 良口乡 **Yangxi 洋溪乡 **Dudong 独峒乡 **Linxi 林溪乡 *[[Liping County]], [[Guizhou]] **Shuikou 水口镇 **Zhaoxing 肇兴乡 **Hongzhou 洪洲镇 **Long'e 龙额乡 **Deshun 德顺乡 **Shunhua 顺化乡 **Diping 地坪乡 **Leidong 雷洞乡 *[[Tongdao Dong Autonomous County]], [[Hunan]] **Dagaoping 大高坪 **Yatunbao 牙屯堡 **Dupo 独坡乡
Sishi Miao 四十苗 is spoken in these townships:<ref name="ShiLin2012"/> *[[Liping County]]: Shuikou 水口镇 (including Qifan 起凡村), Zhaoxing 肇兴乡, Yongcong 永从乡 *[[Rongjiang County]]: Luoxiang 洛香镇
The Flowery Miao live in Luoxiang 洛香镇, Congjiang County; Guochong 锅冲乡 and Dagaoping 大高坪, Tongdao County; Deshun 德顺乡, Liping County. In Liping County, they are also known as the "Flowery-Clothed Miao" (花衣苗) (''Liping County Almanac'' 1989:153). According to Shi Lin (2012), Flowery Miao 花苗 (Ershi Miao 二十苗) is spoken in these townships:<ref name="ShiLin2012"/> *[[Liping County]]: Deshun 德顺乡 *[[Tongdao Dong Autonomous County|Tongdao County]]: Guochong 锅冲乡 (including Kenxi 肯溪村), Dagaoping 大高坪乡, Boyang 播阳乡, Xianxi 县溪镇 *[[Jingzhou Miao and Dong Autonomous County|Jingzhou County]]: Xinchang 新厂镇
Other Cao Miao locations include:<ref>http://www.caomiao.net/</ref> *[[Liping County]], Guizhou **Tangbi Village 塘婢村, Leidong Township 雷洞乡 **Jiujue Village 九厥村, Hongzhou Township 洪州镇 **Guigong 归公, Diping Township 地坪乡 **Guibai 归白, Diping Township 地坪乡 **Pingsong 平松, Shuikou Township 水口镇 **Bashan 八善, Shuikou Township 水口镇 **Gaoze Village 高泽村, Shunhua Township 顺化乡 *[[Sanjiang Dong Autonomous County]], Guangxi **Fenshui 汾水, Bajiang Township 八江乡 **Gaoya 高亚, Dudong Township 独峒乡 *[[Rongshui Miao Autonomous County]], Guangxi<ref>http://comonca.org.cn/lh/doc/A13.pdf</ref> **Rongtang Village 荣塘村, Sirong Township 四荣乡

{{about||the ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'' episode|Change of Command (M*A*S*H episode)|the science fiction novel|Change of Command (novel)}} [[File:55 Wing Change of Command.jpg|275px|right|thumb|Col. Jim Jones (right) accepts the [[55th Wing|55th Wing’s]] [[Guidon (United States)|guidon]] from [[Eighth Air Force]] Commander Lt. Gen. [[Robert J. Elder, Jr.]] (left) during a wing change of command ceremony at [[Offutt Air Force Base]], Nebraska, USA.]] [[File:Sertijab Danyon Arhanudse-14 ( 6 ).jpg|thumb|275px|An [[Indonesian Army]] Change of command ceremony from Lt. Col Tri Sugiyanto to Major Sudrajat of the 14th Medium [[Air Defense]] [[Artillery]] [[Battalion]], [[Cirebon]]]] A '''change of command''' is a military tradition that represents a formal transfer of authority and responsibility for a unit from one [[Commanding officer|commanding]] or [[flag officer]] to another. The passing of [[Colours, standards and guidons|colors]], [[War flag|standards]], or [[ensigns]] from an outgoing commander to an incoming one ensures that the unit and its soldiers is never without official leadership, a continuation of trust, and also signifies an allegiance of soldiers to their unit's commander.
Great symbolism is attached to the ceremonial aspects of a change of command.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p8U_LOzzKnc The Passage of the Commandants - Gen. Amos takes command of the Marine Corps] minute 2:41 and following/13:16. This is also the citation for the coupled sets of orders below, the first for the outgoing commander minute 2:46/13:16, the second for the incoming commander minute 3:13/1316</ref> An inspection and review of soldiers, [[21 gun salute|gun salutes]], as well as a [[military band]] will often be incorporated into the ceremony.<ref>{{cite news|title=Sequence of Events for Change of Command Ceremony|publisher=United States Army|url=http://www.hqusareur.army.mil/band/img/PDF/sample_ceremony.PDF}}{{Dead link|date=August 2012}}</ref>
For a Command Sergeant Major, the transferred item might be a saber during a Change of Responsibility, while for a Chaplain, the item might be the passing of a [[Stole (vestment)|Clerical Stole]].<ref>[https://www.army.mil/article/207991/i_corps_change_of_stole_ceremony I Corps Change of Stole Ceremony]</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[3-volley salute]] *[[21-gun salute]] *[[Burial at sea]] *[[Casing of the Colors]] *[[Color guard]] *[[Half-staff]] *[[Honor guard]] *[[Military funeral]] *[[Military rites]] *[[Missing man formation]] *[[Riderless horse]] *[[State funeral]] *[[Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]] {{div col end}}
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}

'''Chumburung''' is a kingdom and traditional area in the western part of [[Kpandai District|Kpandae District]] in the [[Northern Region (Ghana)|Northern Region]] of [[Ghana]]. It is the homeland of the [[Chumburu]], but [[Bassar]]i, [[Gonja people|Gonja]]s, [[Kokomba people|Kokomba]]s and [[Nawuri]](s) are also indigenous in the area. Land, however, can only be acquired with the permission of the village chief and the king, who are both natives and officials of the Chumburung kingdom. '''Chumburung''' is also the name of the [[Chumburung language|language]] of the Chumburu.
The kingdom of Chumburung encompasses a number of villages at both sides of the [[Dakar River]], from [[Kojobonipe]] in the North to [[Lonto]] in the South-West and [[Wiae]] in the East, both on the shores of [[Lake Volta]]. Other towns and villages in the kingdom, roughly from North to South, are [[Ekumdepe]] (Kumdi for short), [[Ba(n)kamba]], [[Chakori, Ghana|Chakori]], [[Nanjiro]], [[Tori, Ghana|Tori]], [[Jamboae]] and [[Kachanka, Ghana|Kachanka]].<ref>http://www.northernghanapeoples.co.uk/ , section about Chumburung, must be corrected in a number of ways. Most important, the kingdom of Chumburung does not spread across Lake Volta toward [[Banda, Ghana|Banda]] and beyond. These parts of [[Volta Region]] belong to the kingdom and traditional area of [[Krachi (disambiguation)|Krachi]]<!--intentional link to DAB page-->. Furthermore, [[Kabesi]] is an exclave of the [[Nawuri]] kingdom around the town of [[Kpandae]].</ref>
Chumburung is remote from the modern world in many senses. The few roads that exist in the area can only be plied by heavy vehicles, such as lorries, Benz buses in good condition, strong pick-ups and 4WD vehicles. Since few inhabitants can afford such means of transport for private use, the most popular vehicle is the motorcycle. Public transport consists of one Benz daily between [[Kpandae]] and [[Salaga]] (leaving Kpandae at dawn, arriving in Salaga around 10 a.m., and returning in the afternoon) and one Benz bus daily between [[Banda, Ghana|Banda]] and Salaga, serving almost all the villages of Chumburung (leaving Banda at dawn and also returning in the afternoon).
Up to now (April, 2014), Chumburung is not connected to any electricity network and few inhabitants have their own generators, but [[Volta River Authority]] is in the process of connecting some of the towns to its grid. The only telephone company that is active in the area is [[MTN Group|MTN]], but inhabitants of Wiae may get coverage from the [[Airtel Africa]] pole in Banda.
The first schools in Chumburung were set up by [[Ashanti people|Ashanti]] teachers in the 1980s; they were later followed by others who started to teach in the local languages including Chumburung.

revision.text:
{{Economics sidebar}} A '''conservation economy''' is an ideal, imagined [[economy]] in which [[Wealth (economics)|economic wealth]] is harvested from a [[Ecoregion|bioregion's]] local [[natural resource]]s in a way that meets local communities' needs yet restores rather than depletes [[natural capital|natural]] and [[social capital|social]] [[Capital (economics)|capital]][http://www.frbkc.org/PUBLICAT/Exploring/RC01Dabs.pdf Dabson, Brian (2001) "Supporting Rural Entrepreneurship" Federal Reserve Bank of Kanasas city website] Accessed 26 January 2010
"In a conservation economy, economic arrangements of all kinds are gradually redesigned so that they restore, rather than deplete, natural capital and social capital...Even in a globalizing economy, diverse bioregional economies that are more self-sufficient in meeting their own needs will be more competitive and less vulnerable..."[http://www.conservationeconomy.net/conservation_economy.html ConservationEconomy.Net's "Conservation Economy" webpage] Accessed 12 January 2010
The primary agents expected to ultimately transform local economies and move bioregions towards locally resilient and enduring 'conservation economies' are small plus medium-sized business owners ('conservation entrepreneurs') who embrace a [[Conservation (ethic)|conservation ethic]] and take a rational self-interest in maintaining and restoring local [[ecosystem]]s
"Individuals and organizations that see its potential and acquire the skills to build [a conservation economy] will create ongoing and enduring economic opportunities. Individuals and organizations that continue to depend on the depletion of social and natural capital will face increasingly unpredictable global commodity markets, tightening laws and regulations, new taxes, public outrage, loss of motivation, and many other symptoms of economic transformation"
Key advocates spending many years taking a lead in promoting the benefits of conservation economies and investing in local businesses to help build conservation economies have been the not-for-profit organization, [[Ecotrust]], (founded in 1991 by economist [[Ecotrust|Spencer Beebe]]) and its partners: Ecotrust Canada, ShoreBank Pacific, and ShoreBank Enterprise Pacific[http://www.conservationeconomy.net/pdfs/Social_Capital_Sustainability.pdf Neilsen-Pincus, Max (2002) "Social Capital & Sustainability: A Qualitative Study of Community Leaders in the Conservation Economy". Conservationeconomy.net website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031216052239/http://www.conservationeconomy.net/pdfs/Social_Capital_Sustainability.pdf |date=2003-12-16 }} Accessed 26 January 2009 ==See also== * [[Ecotrust]] * [[Ecological economics]] * [[Environmental economics]] * [[Green economy]] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Economy and the environment]]

revision.comment: /* United States */ the tax exemption has little to do with cost
revision.text:
The '''cost of raising a child''' varies from country to country. The cost of raising a child is usually determined according to a formula that accounts for major areas of expenditure, such as food, housing, and clothing. However, any given family's actual expenses may differ from the estimates. For example, the [[renting|rent]] on a home does not usually change when the tenants have another child, so the family's housing costs may remain the same. In other cases, the home may be too small, in which case the family might move to a larger home at a higher cost. ==Developing countries== According to Globalissues.org, "Almost half the world—over three billion people—live on less than $2.50 a day."{{cite web | last = Shah | first = Anup | title = Poverty Facts and Stats | publisher = Global Issues | date = September 20, 2010 | url = http://www.globalissues.org/article/26/poverty-facts-and-stats | accessdate = August 5, 2012}} This [[statistic]] includes children. Based on UNICEF statistics, in developing countries the cost is roughly [[US Dollar|US$]]900 for raising a child for a year, and US$16,200 for raising a child from birth to age 17.[http://www.unicef.org/sowc05/english/index.html State of the World's Children, 2005], UNICEF (This calculation is difficult, since families in developing countries often do not operate with currency, but barter or trade to provide for their children.)Martin Ravallion, Shaohua Chen and Prem Sangraula, [http://go.worldbank.org/3KL75ZFJ60 Dollar a day revisited], World Bank, May 2008 Half of all children in the world live in [[poverty]]. ==United Kingdom== The annual LV= ([[Liverpool Victoria]]) Cost of a Child report calculates the cost of raising a child from birth to 21 years old. The latest report puts the cost as £231,843.{{Cite web|url=https://www.lv.com/life-cover/cost-of-a-child|title=Cost of a child {{!}} LV=|website=www.lv.com|access-date=2016-06-27}} The Cost of a child calculations, from birth to 21 years, were compiled by the Centre of Economic and Business Research (CEBR) for LV= in December 2015 and are based on the cost for the 21-year period to December 2015. Additional research was conducted by [[Opinium Research LLP]] from 22 to 27 January 2016. The total sample size was 1,000 UK adults with children under the age of 18 and was conducted online. Results have been weighted to nationally representative criteria ==United States== Based on a [[Statistical survey|survey]] by the [[U.S. Department of Agriculture]], the table below shows the estimated Average Spending on Children by Families. The data comes from the Consumer Expenditure Survey by the [[U.S. Department of Labor]], conducted from 2005-06. The figures have been updated to 2011 dollars using the [[Consumer Price Index]]. However, some dispute the numbers as being biased high for political reasons (e.g., Texas A&M University Finance Professor H. Swint Friday: "The numbers, reported by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, are outrageously misleading. Often government statistics are produced for political objectives that cause the research methodology to be biased toward finding the highest dollar amount to support the objective."{{cite web | last = Friday| first = H. Swint| title = Cost of raising children not as high as government would have you believe | publisher = caller.com | date = July 20, 2007 | url = http://www.caller.com/news/2007/jul/20/cost-of-raising-children-not-as-high-as-would/ | accessdate = March 31, 2013}}). These figures from the USDA go up to age 18, and do not include any [[higher education|college or university education]]. Nor does it offer any spending estimates if the child remains in the home as a [[Dependant|dependent]] after the age of 18.http://abcnews.go.com/Business/page?id=4019746 Both tables are for the [[United States]] overall, not based on any specific region in the country. ===Dual-Parent Family - USDA Average Spending per Child (not the basic cost of raising)=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: right;" |+ Dual-Parent Family - USDA Average Spending per Child (not the basic cost of raising){{cite web|url=http://www.cnpp.usda.gov/Publications/CRC/crc2011.pdf|title=Expenditures on Children by Families, 2011 (Miscellaneous Publication Number 1528-2011)|last=Lino|first=Mark|publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]], Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion|format=PDF|accessdate=August 5, 2012}} ! || style="background-color: #dfd;"|'''333,420''' |} All numbers are in [[United States dollar|US dollars]]. == India == Based on an estimate by [[The Economic Times|Economic Times]] in April 2011, the cost of raising a child from birth to age of majority (21 Years) for a middle to upper-middle income family comes to about {{INRConvert|55|l}} in total.{{cite web |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/photo.cms?msid=7998976 |title=How much it cost to raise a child |date=18 April 2011 |accessdate=13 July 2016 |work=report |publisher=Economic Times |author= '''100%''' |} Note: Estimate assumes cost of birth, but doesn't consider any major illness in child. ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Only child]] *[[Child care]] *[[Child support]] *[[Childfree]] *[[Cost of living]] *[[Demographic economics]] *[[Family economics]] *[[Family planning]] *[[Family values]] *[[Single parent]] *[[Middle-class squeeze]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/03/24/us-usa-children-idUSN2431320820080324 "Raising that '07 baby will cost $204,060 in U.S."] - from [[Reuters]], retrieved August 5, 2012. *[http://www.caller.com/news/2007/jul/20/cost-of-raising-children-not-as-high-as-would/ "Cost of raising children not as high as government would have you believe"] - from caller.com, retrieved March 31, 2013. *"[http://www.globelifeinsurance.com/the-cost-of-raising-children-in-the-us.html Cost of Raising Children in the US]" - from Globe Life Insurance, retrieved September 11, 2013 {{Parenting}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cost Of Raising A Child}} [[Category:Parenting]] [[Category:Family]] [[Category:Marriage]] [[Category:Demographic economics]]
