revision.text:
{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Italian Scot
''Italo-scozzesi'' |population = No exact numbers but estimates range from 35,000 to 100,000 |popplace = Throughout Scotland specifically [[Glasgow]]{{·}} |langs = [[Scots language|Scots]]{{·}}[[English Language|English]]{{·}}[[Italian language|Italian]] (and related [[List of languages of Italy|forms]]) |rels = [[Roman Catholicism]]{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} |related = [[Italian people|Italian]], [[Welsh Italians]], [[Italian Americans]], [[Italian Australians]], [[Italian Canadians]] }} '''Italian Scots''' or '''Scots-Italians''' are people of [[Italian people|Italian]] descent living in [[Scotland]]. These terms may refer to people who are born in Scotland and of Italian descent. It can also refer to people of mixed Scottish and Italian ancestry. A recent Italian voter census estimated that there are 70,000 to 100,000 people in Scotland of Italian descent or Italian nationals, which is up to 1.9% of the overall Scottish population. Latest available figures from the [[2011 UK Census]] show there were 6,048 people born in Italy living in Scotland. This was up from 4,936 in 2001 and 3,947 recorded in 1991.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/what-impact-have-scots-italians-had-on-scotland-1-4025475|title=What impact have Scots-Italians had on Scotland?|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}} In 2016, Ronnie Convery, secretary of the Italian Scotland charitable organisation and director of communications at the [[Archdiocese of Glasgow]], asserted that a completely new dimension was being added to the Scots-Italians community. He said, “There has been a brand new migration over the past two years, and the biggest one we have seen in 100 years."{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/what-impact-have-scots-italians-had-on-scotland-1-4025475|title=What impact have Scots-Italians had on Scotland?|website=www.scotsman.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}} The majority come from the provinces of [[Province of Lucca|Lucca]], [[Province of Parma|Parma]], [[Province of Frosinone|Frosinone]] and [[Province of Isernia|Isernia]].{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} ==History== Arguably the first people from [[Italy]] to reach Scotland were the [[Roman Empire|Romans]] in and around 40CE, although the modern nation of Italy did not exist at the time and of course the Roman Empire was a cosmopolitan institution, with some [[Roman Emperors]] from the [[Iberian Peninsula]] and [[North Africa]]. Still, the Romans were for the most part from what is now Italy and they did leave their mark on Scotland in the shape of [[Hadrian's Wall]], [[Antonine Wall]] and other monumental constructions, although it was not until the end of the 19th century that an Italian-Scots identity really began to take shape. Many Italian-Scots can trace their ancestry back to the 1890s where their forefathers escaped [[drought]], [[famine]] and [[poverty]] in their homeland for a better life in Scotland; yet it was not until [[World War I]] that a sizeable population of Italian-Scots—over 4,000{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/3976689.stm| title=Italian role in Scotland honoured| publisher=BBC News| date=3 November 2004| accessdate=2008-03-16}}—began to emerge, with [[Glasgow]] hosting the third largest community in the [[United Kingdom]]. Since then, there has been a steady flow of [[Human migration|migration]] between the two countries. Italy and the [[fascist]] involvement in [[World War II]] brought many hardships on Italians settled in Scotland - many families were separated as adult males were [[interned]].{{cite web| url=http://www.scotsitalian.com/history.htm| title=History| publisher=ScotsItalian.com| accessdate=2008-03-16}} The family members that were left behind were forced to cope with mistrust and [[discrimination]]. Of those imprisoned many men found themselves held in [[Northern Ireland]] and the [[Isle of Man]]. A number of others were employed in [[Orkney]], at [[Scapa Flow]], to construct a barrier against [[Nazism|Nazi]] [[U-boats]]. These men additionally constructed the [[Italian Chapel|Chapel of Lambholm]] from scrap metal and junk.{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/heritage/scotland/highland/article_1.shtml| title=Orkney's Italian Gift| publisher=BBC| accessdate=2008-03-16}} Nowadays, this Chapel is one of Orkney's most popular tourist attractions. Today, Italian Scots can be found working in all manner of [[profession]]s. However, a large proportion of the community have plied their trade in the [[catering]] industry, working in the [[fish and chips|chip shops]], [[ice-cream]] parlours, [[pizzeria]]s and [[restaurants]] across Scotland. In Edinburgh,The Italo-Scottish Research Cluster (ISRC) aims to study Italian immigration in Scotland and promote relations between Scotland and Italy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ed.ac.uk/literatures-languages-cultures/delc/italian/italo-scottish-research-cluster/about|title=About us|work=The University of Edinburgh|access-date=2017-11-09|language=en}} == Notable Italian Scots == {{colbegin}} * [[John Amabile (interior designer)|John Amabile]], interior designer * [[Ronni Ancona]], impressionist and actress * [[Nicola Benedetti]], violinist * [[Romana D'Annunzio]], television presenter * [[Junior Campbell]], musician and composer * [[Gianni Capaldi]], actor * [[Peter Capaldi]], actor and director * [[Emilio Coia]], caricaturist * [[Jack Coia]], architect * [[Paul Coia]], television presenter * [[Angela Constance]], [[Scottish National Party]] MSP * [[Mario Joseph Conti]], [[emeritus]] [[Archbishop of Glasgow]] * [[Tom Conti]], actor * [[Nina Conti]], actor, impressionist and comedian * [[Adrienne Corri]], actress * [[Simon Danielli]], rugby union player * [[Richard Demarco]], art impresario * [[Sophia Dussek]], musician * [[Paul di Giacomo]], footballer * [[Linda Fabiani]], [[Scottish National Party]] MSP, and former Minister for Culture. * [[Charles Forte, Baron Forte|Charles Forte]], hotelier * [[Rocco Forte]], hotelier * [[Dario Franchitti]], [[Racecar driver]] * [[Marino Franchitti]], [[Racecar driver]] * [[Chris Fusaro]], rugby player * [[Armando Iannucci]], writer and satirist * [[Keira Lucchesi]], actress * [[Lou Macari]], footballer and football manager * [[Peter Marinello]], footballer * [[Oscar Marzaroli]], photographer * [[Dominic Matteo]], footballer * [[Kirsty Mitchell]], actress * [[Alberto Morrocco]], artist * [[Giovanni Moscardini]], footballer * Sir [[Anton Muscatelli]], [[Principal of the University of Glasgow|Principal and Vice-Chancellor
of the University of Glasgow]] * [[Daniela Nardini]], actress * [[Paolo Nutini]], singer-songwriter * Sir [[Eduardo Paolozzi]], sculptor * [[Carmen Pieraccini]], actress * [[Paul di Resta]], [[F1 drivers|Formula 1 racecar driver]] * [[David Rizzio]], private secretary of Mary, Queen of Scots * [[Marcus di Rollo]], rugby player * [[Carla Romano]], TV journalist * [[George Rossi]], actor * [[Ricky Sbragia]], footballer * [[Tom Sermanni]], football coach * [[Rachel Sermanni]], singer-songwriter * [[Sharleen Spiteri]], singer-songwriter; guitarist; lead vocalist of the [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[pop rock|pop-rock]] band [[Texas (band)|Texas]] * [[Ken Stott]], actor * [[Philip Tartaglia]], [[Archbishop of Glasgow]] * [[Alexander Trocchi]], writer * [[Peter Vettese]], musician * [[Lena Zavaroni]], singer{{colend}} ==In popular culture== *''[[American Cousins]]'' – A film about an Italian Scots family and their [[American Mafia|Mafia]] associated American cousins. *''[[Strictly Sinatra]]'' *''[[Comfort and Joy (1984 film)|Comfort and Joy]]'' – A film about a war between rival Italian ice cream companies in Glasgow. The film is a spoof of American gangster movies. *''[[Soft Top Hard Shoulder]]'' == See also == {{portal|Scotland|Italy}} * [[Italian migration to Britain]] * [[Immigration to the United Kingdom]] * [[Italian diaspora]] * [[List of British Italians]] * Italian Scot communities of [[Filignano]] and [[Cerasuolo]] == References == {{reflist}} *Pieri, J. (2005) 'The Scots-Italians: Recollections of an Immigrant' The Mercat Press {{Italian diaspora}} [[Category:Scottish people of Italian descent| ]] [[Category:Italian diaspora in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Italian diaspora by country]] [[Category:Immigration to Scotland]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Scotland]]

The '''Kereyu Oromo people''' (also Karrayu, Karrayyuu) are an [[Oromo people|Oromo]] subgroup inhabiting the [[Awash Valley]] in central [[Ethiopia]]. They are [[Pastoralism|pastoralists]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KYmMCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA30|title=Understanding Contemporary Ethiopia|last=Prunier|first=Gérard|date=2015|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9781849042611|location=|pages=30|language=en}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of Oromo subgroups and clans]]
== References == {{Reflist}}{{Ethnic groups in Ethiopia}}{{Ethiopia-ethno-group-stub}}
[[Category:Ethnic groups in Ethiopia]] [[Category:Oromo groups]]

{{distinguish|Ati language}} {{Infobox language |name = Kuteb |nativename = Ati |states = [[Nigeria]], [[Cameroon]] |region = [[Taraba State]] |ethnicity = [[Kuteb people]] |speakers = 46,000 |date=2000 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Niger-Congo |fam2=[[Atlantic–Congo]] |fam3=[[Benue–Congo languages|Benue–Congo]] |fam4= [[Jukunoid languages|Jukunoid]] |fam5= |iso3=kub |glotto=kute1248 |glottorefname=Kutep }} '''Kuteb''' (Also known as ''Kutep'' or ''Ati'') is a [[Jukunoid language]] of [[Nigeria]], spoken by the [[Kuteb people]], with a thousand-or-so speakers across the border in [[Cameroon]]. == Phonology == In Kuteb, there are 27 consonant phonemes, 12 vowels , and five tones.Blench, Roger. [http://www.rogerblench.info/Language/Niger-Congo/BC/Jukunoid/Kuteb%20grammar%20for%20KWEF%20ed%20RMB%20December%202007.doc ''Kuteb grammar'']. p. 19 === Vowels === In Kuteb, there are two different sets of vowels, oral, and nasal. Phonemically, each set has six different [[vowel]]s. In total, there are 12 separate phonemes. The status of ''ɨ'' being a phoneme in Kuteb is uncertain. This phoneme only occurs in closed syllables, some noun prefixes, and in verbal reduplication where there is neutralization of ''u'' and ''i''. {| class="wikitable" |+Table of vowel phonemes in Kuteb ! rowspan="2" | ! colspan="3" |Oral Vowels ! colspan="3" |Nasal Vowels |- ![[Front vowel|Front]] ![[Central vowel|Central]] ![[Back vowel|Back]] ![[Front vowel|Front]] ![[Central vowel|Central]] ![[Back vowel|Back]] |- style="text-align:center;" ![[Close vowel|Close]] |i {{IPAslink|i}} |''ɨ'' {{IPAslink|ɨ }} |u {{IPAslink|u}} |ĩ {{IPAslink|ĩ}} | |ũ {{IPAslink|ũ}} |- style="text-align:center;" ![[Mid vowel|Close Mid]] |e {{IPAslink|e}} | |o {{IPAslink|o}} |ē {{IPAslink|ẽ}} | |ō {{IPAslink|õ}} |- style="text-align:center;" ![[Near-open vowel|Near Open]] |ae {{IPAslink|æ}} | | |ãe {{IPAslink|æ̃}} | | |- style="text-align:center;" ![[Open vowel|Open]] | |a {{IPAslink|a}} | | |ã {{IPAslink|ã}} | |} === Consonants === Kuteb has 27 different [[consonant]] phonemes. The italicized entries are found in common loan words, or, in the case of /v/ and /z/, subdialectical variation. Like most [[Jukunoid languages]], Kuteb has velarized consonants. In one study, these are included not as modifications on the base-phoneme, but as their own separate sound.{{Cite book|title=Comparative Jukunoid|last=Kiyoshi|first=Shimizu|publisher=Veröffentlichungen des Instituts für Afrikanistik und Ägyptlogie der Universität Wien|year=1980|isbn=|location=Vienna, Austria|pages=66}}Blench, Roger. [http://www.rogerblench.info/Language/Niger-Congo/BC/Jukunoid/Kuteb%20grammar%20for%20KWEF%20ed%20RMB%20December%202007.doc ''Kuteb grammar'']. p. 20'''' {| class="wikitable" style="margin:autmargin:auto;" |+Table of consonant phonemes in Kuteb ! colspan="2" | ![[Labial consonant|Labial]] ![[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ![[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ![[Velar consonant|Velar]] ![[Glottalic consonant|Glottal]] |- style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" |[[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] |m {{IPAslink|m}} |n, nn In the standard Kuteb orthography, ⟨n⟩ is used initially and medially for /n/, while ⟨nn⟩ is used finally {{IPAslink|n}} |ny {{IPAslink|ɲ}} |ŋ {{IPAslink|ŋ}} | |- style="text-align:center;" ! rowspan="3" |[[Plosive]] ![[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] |b {{IPAslink|b}} |''d'' {{IPAslink|d}} | |g {{IPAslink|g}} | |- style="text-align:center;" ![[Voice (phonetics)|unvoiced]] |p {{IPAslink|p}} |t {{IPAslink|t}} |c {{IPAslink|c}} |k {{IPAslink|k}} | |- style="text-align:center;" ![[Prenasalized consonant|pre-nasal]]
[[Prenasalized consonant|voiced]] |mb /[[Prenasalized consonant|m͡b]]/ |nd /[[Prenasalized consonant|n͡d]]/ |nj /[[Prenasalized consonant|n͡ʒ]]/ |ŋg /[[Prenasalized consonant|ŋ͡g]]/ | |- style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" |[[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] | |ts {{IPAslink|t͡s}} | | | |- style="text-align:center;" ! rowspan="2" |[[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] ![[Voice (phonetics)|voiced]] |''v'' {{IPAslink|v}} |''z'' {{IPAslink|z}} |j {{IPAslink|ʒ}} | | |- style="text-align:center;" ![[Voice (phonetics)|unvoiced]] |f {{IPAslink|f}} |s {{IPAslink|s}} |sh {{IPAslink|ʃ}} | |h {{IPAslink|h}} |- style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" |[[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | | |y {{IPAslink|j}} |w {{IPAslink|w}} | |- style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" |[[Flap consonant|Flap]] | |r {{IPAslink|ɾ}} | | | |- style="text-align:center;" ! colspan="2" |[[Lateral approximant|Lateral-Approximant]] | |''l'' {{IPAslink|l}} | | | |} === Tones === In Kuteb, there are either four or five different tones, depending on how they are counted. The tones that are accepted by multiple studies are the low (unmarked), mid (¯), high (´), and falling (ˆ) tones. ==== Arguments ==== According to [[Roger Blench]], there are five different tones in Kuteb, these are: low (unmarked), mid (¯), high (´), falling (ˆ), and rising (ˇ). The fifth tone, (rising) is only created through sandhi changes that affect some vocabulary after an "upstep". According to W.E. Welmers, this sandhi change does not occur, and if it did, only the pronunciation would change, not the written diacritic as well.{{Cite book|title=The Phonology and Morphology of Kuteb ''(unpublished)''|last=Welmers|first=W.E.|publisher=Sudan United Mission|year=1948|isbn=|location=|pages=105 & 173}} === Phonotactics === ==== Syllabic boundaries ==== In Kutep, like in other Jukunoid languages, most consonantal phonemes can either be [[Labialization|labialized]] or [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatal]]. If these changes are taken to be consonantal phonemic clusters, the syllabic boundaries are as follows:Blench, Roger. [http://www.rogerblench.info/Language/Niger-Congo/BC/Jukunoid/Kuteb%20grammar%20for%20KWEF%20ed%20RMB%20December%202007.doc ''Kuteb grammar'']. p. 53–54 {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="4" |N - syllabic nasal, V - vowel, C - consonant |- ! !Kuteb (divided '''syllabically)''' !Kuteb !English translation |- !N |ḿ.m |[[wiktionary:ḿm|ḿm]] |no |- !V |u.fu |[[wiktionary:ufu|ufu]] |door |- !CV |bá |[[wiktionary:bá|bá]] |come |- !CVC |mūm |[[wiktionary:mūm|mūm]] |dig |- !CCV |u.kwe |[[wiktionary:ukwe|ukwe]] |chief |- !CCVC |kwáb |[[wiktionary:kwáb|kwáb]] |try |} ==== Sandhi changes ==== The letter ⟨w⟩ in the Kuteb language retains its status as a [[voiced labio-velar approximant]], as in ''uwé'' ‘face’ or in ''wōm'' ‘dry’ - though, when ⟨w⟩ is included in clusters with a palatal consonant (/c, j, sh, nj/) /w/, due to sandhi changes, becomes a voiced or voiceless labiodental release. ==== Distribution of consonants ==== In Kuteb, there are many consonant clusters that can exist, though, most of these occur between word boundaries, though, some of these do occur in single-syllable isolation - these syllables are listed below. Theoretically though, any combination of syllable-final consonants (see below) followed by any syllable-initial consonant is possible. It is likely, however, that reduction would occur, as in the word ''ushitong'' ‘soup-stirrer’ (from ''shir'' and ''utoŋ'') in which the /r/ has been dropped. Also, when final ⟨nn⟩ stems precede stems beginning with ⟨n⟩, the double ⟨nn⟩+⟨n⟩ is reduced to just ⟨n⟩. This effect can be shown in words such as ''munae'' (munn-náe) ‘be abundant’, and in ''munji'' (munn-nji) ‘forget’.Blench, Roger. [http://www.rogerblench.info/Language/Niger-Congo/BC/Jukunoid/Kuteb%20grammar%20for%20KWEF%20ed%20RMB%20December%202007.doc ''Kuteb grammar'']. p. 37–38 In CV positions, the following consonants are used: * p ts t c k b (d) (g) mb nd nj ŋg f s sh h v z nz m n ŋ r l While in C(C)VC final positions, the following are used instead: * b r g m n* ŋ'''*''' And the following are used in CC clusters: * ''With Cw'': pw, mbw, bw, fw, mw, sw (?), cw, njw, jw, shw, kw, ngw, and ŋw Roger Blench notes that ⟨[[Eng (letter)|ŋ]]⟩ and ⟨ng⟩ are equivalent in the standard orthography. Here, both ⟨ŋw⟩ and ⟨ngw⟩ are listed as separate phonemes, though, the difference between them is not given * ''With Cy'': py, mby * ''With Ck'': pk, tk, fk, sk * ''With Cg'': mbg, ndg ==== Consonant clusters ==== In 1964, Peter Ladefoged recorded the phonetics of multiple West African languages. One of these languages was Kuteb, and these were his findings:{{Cite book|title=A phonetic study of west African languages|last=Ladefoged|first=Peter|publisher=Cambridge University|year=1964|isbn=0-521-06963-7|location=Cambridge|pages=31}} {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="3" |Labial ! rowspan="2" |Dental ! rowspan="2" |Alveolar ! rowspan="2" |Palatal ! rowspan="2" |Post-palatal ! rowspan="2" |Velar |- !With /w/ !With /y/ !With /ɣ/ or /x/ |- |pw |py |px |ts |tx |tʃ |tɕf |kw |- |mbw |mby |mbɣ |ndz |ndɣ |ndʒ |ndʑv |ŋgw |- |bw |by |bɣ | | |dʒ |dʑv |(gw) |- |fw |fy |fx | |sk | |ʃf | |- |mw |my |(mɣ) | | |nay | |ŋw |} == Notes == ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *http://www.koeppe.de/titel_details.php?id=514 *http://lingweb.eva.mpg.de/numeral/Kuteb.htm *http://www.koeppe.de/titel_details_print.php?id=514 *http://globalrecordings.net/en/language/1757 *[http://main.journalofwestafricanlanguages.org/index.php/downloads/send/25-volume0901/125-the-recapitulating-pronouns-in-kuteb The Recapitulating Pronouns in Kuteb] {{Platoid languages}} [[Category:Jukunoid languages]] [[Category:Languages of Nigeria]] [[Category:Languages of Cameroon]]

* '''[[Luis Manzano]]''' (5): ''"Best Male New TV Personality", "Best Male Showbiz-Oriented Show Host", "Best Talent Search Program Host", "Best Game Show Host"'' and ''"Best Male TV Host"''. * '''[[Boy Abunda]]''' (4): ''"Best Male Showbiz-Oriented Show Host"'' (Hall of Famer), ''"Best Celebrity Talk Show Host"'' (shared)'', ''"Best Public Affairs Program Host"'' and ''"Best Magazine Show Host"''. * '''[[Kris Aquino]]''' (4): ''"Best Female Showbiz-Oriented Show Host", "Best Celebrity Talk Show Host"'' (shared), ''"Best Game Show Host"'' and ''"Best Lifestyle Program Host'' * '''[[Toni Gonzaga]]''' (4): ''"Best Female Showbiz-Oriented Show Host", "Best Reality Show Host"'' (shared), ''"Best Talent Search Program Host"'' (shared) and ''"Best Female TV Host"''. * '''[[Judy Ann Santos]]''' (4): ''"Best Drama Actress", "Best Reality Show Host", "Best Game Show Host",'' and ''"Best Single Performance by an Actress"''. * '''[[Kim Chiu]]''' (4): ''"Best Female New TV Personality", ''"Best Drama Actress"'', ''Best Single Performance by An Actress"'' and ''"Best Talent Search Program Host"'' (shared). * '''[[Nora Aunor]]''' (3):''"Best Female TV Host"'',''"Best Drama Actess''" and ''Best Single Performance by an Actress ''". * '''[[Vic Sotto]]''' (3): ''"Best Male TV Host"'', ''"Best Comedy Actor"'' and ''"Best Game Show Host"''. * '''[[Korina Sanchez]]''' (3): ''"Best Female Newscaster"'', ''"Best Celebrity Talk Show Host"'' (shared) and ''"Best Magazine Show Host"''. * '''[[Arjo Atayde]]''' (3): ''"Best Male New TV Personality", "Best Single Performance by an Actor"'' and ''"Best Drama Supporting Actor"''. * '''[[Claudine Barretto]]''' (3): ''"Best New TV Personality", "Best Female TV Host"'' and ''"Best Single Performance by an Actress"''. * '''[[Marian Rivera]]''' (3): ''"Best Female New TV Personality", "Best Drama Actress"'' and ''"Best Female TV Host"''. * '''[[Julius Babao]]''' (3): ''"Best Male Newscaster", "Best Morning Show Host"'' (shared) and ''"Best Public Service Program Host"''. * '''[[Ai-Ai delas Alas]]''' (3): ''"Best Comedy Actress", "Best Game Show Host"'' (shared) and ''"Best Single Performance by an Actress"''. * '''[[Robi Domingo]]''' (3): ''"Best Male New TV Personality", "Best Talent Search Program Host"'' (shared) and ''"Best Reality Show Host"'' (shared). * '''[[Willie Revillame]]''' (3): ''"Best Public Service Program Host", "Best Male TV Host"'' and ''"Best Game Show Host"''.

This is a list about [[blood donation]] agencies in different countries.
== Australia == * [[Australian Red Cross Blood Service]]
== Bangladesh == {{Main|Blood donation in Bangladesh}} * [[Bangladesh Red Crescent Society]] * [[Sandhani]] * [[Red Drop]] * [[Badhon]] *Tremendous Blood Bank
== Belgium == * [[Belgian Red Cross]]<ref>https://www.rodekruis.be/wat-doen-we/bloedvoorziening/</ref>
== Canada == * [[Canadian Blood Services]] * [[Héma-Québec]], provincial, independent from the Canadian Blood Services.
== Finland == * Veripalvelu ([[Finnish Red Cross]] Blood Service)
== Germany == * [[German Red Cross]]<ref>https://www.drk-blutspende.de/</ref>
== Hong Kong == *[[Hong Kong Red Cross|Hong Kong Red Cross Blood Transfusion Service]]
== India == {{Main|Blood donation in India}} * [[Blood Cross Society]] * [[Rotary Blood Bank]] * [[The Blood Association]] * [[Friends2support]] * [[Indian Red Cross Society]] * [[No More Thalassemia]] * [[Sankalp India Foundation]] * [[Athar Blood Bank]] * [[National Blood Transfusion Council]
== Indonesia == * [[Indonesian Red Cross Society]]
== Ireland == * [[Irish Blood Transfusion Service]]
== Israel == * [[Magen David Adom]]
== Italy == * [[Associazione Volontari Italiani Sangue]] (AVIS) * [[Italian Red Cross]]
== Japan == * [[Japanese Red Cross]]
== Malaysia == * [[National Blood Centre (Malaysia)|National Blood Centre]]
== Nepal == * [[Nepal Red Cross Society]] * [[Youth For Blood]]
== New Zealand == * [[New Zealand Blood Service]]
== Nigeria == * LifebloodNigeria
== Philippines == * [[Philippine Red Cross]]
== Singapore == * [[Health Sciences Authority]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsa.gov.sg/publish/hsaportal/en/health_services/blood_donation.html/|title=Health Sciences Authority}}</ref>
== South Africa == * [[South African National Blood Service]] * Western Province Blood Transfusion Service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpblood.org.za/|title=Western Province Blood Transfusion Service}}</ref>
== Thailand == * [[Thai Red Cross Society]]
==United Kingdom== * [[NHS Blood and Transplant]] * [[Northern Ireland Blood Transfusion Service]] * [[Scottish National Blood Transfusion Service]] * [[Welsh Blood Service]]
==United States== {{Main|List of blood donation agencies in the United States}}
The United States does not have a centralized blood donation service. The [[American Red Cross]] collects a little less than half of the blood used, the other half is collected by independent agencies, most of which are members of [[America's Blood Centers]]. The US military collects blood from service members for its own use, but also draws blood from the civilian supply.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.militaryblood.dod.mil/ |title=Armed Services Blood Program: The Official Program for Blood Donation and Collection for the Armed Services |publisher=Militaryblood.dod.mil |date= |accessdate=2016-03-28}}</ref>
==See also== * [[World Blood Donor Day]]

revision.text:
{{Criticism section|date=July 2018}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} {{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox website | alexa = {{DecreasePositive}} 1,220 ({{as of |2018|2|5|alt=January 2018}})<ref name="alexa">{{cite web |url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/Liveleak.com |title= Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= 2 June 2015 }}</ref> | area_served = Worldwide | caption = Screenshot of Liveleak's homepage | name = LiveLeak | logo = [[Image:Liveleak logo july 2014.png|Liveleak logo|280px]] | current_status = Active<ref name=alexa/> | foundation = {{start date and age|df=y|2006|10|31}}<ref name="Roversi">{{cite book|last1=Roversi|first1=Antonio|title=Hate on the Net: Extremist Sites, Neo-fascism On-line, Electronic Jihad|date=2008|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd|isbn=9780754672142|pages=8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hp5m9TDgIXYC&lpg=PA8&ots=mM8twGcMM5&dq=liveleak%2031%20october%202006&pg=PA8#v=onepage&q=liveleak%2031%20october%202006&f=false|accessdate=21 August 2017|quote=The website [Ogrish.com] was incorporated into LiveLeak.com on 31 October 2006}}</ref><ref name="BI 2014">{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=James|title=Q&A: The Man Behind LiveLeak, The Islamic State's Favourite Site For Beheading Videos|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/profile-of-hayden-hewitt-founder-of-liveleak-2014-10|website=Business Insider UK|accessdate=21 August 2017|date=7 November 2014|quote=[...]on Halloween 2006, Ogrish abruptly shut down, directing its users to visit a new video service: LiveLeak.}}</ref> | founder = Various co-founders including Hayden Hewitt<ref name="Q&A" />
| url = {{URL|liveleak.com|}} | commercial = Yes | type = [[Video hosting service|Video sharing]] | registration = Optional | location_city = London<ref>{{cite web|title=Company Overview of LiveLeak|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=34880583|website=Bloomberg|publisher=S&P Global Market Intelligence|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> | location_country = United Kingdom | owner = Unknown | author = Hayden Hewitt <small>(co-founder)</small> | screenschot = }} '''LiveLeak''' is a [[Video hosting service|video sharing]] website located in London, United Kingdom that lets users post and share videos. The site was founded on 31 October 2006,<ref>[http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=b8e_1193855061 Damn, a year already?] ''liveleak.com'', 31 October 2007</ref> launched as a tamer version of the [[Ogrish.com]] [[shock site]];<ref name="Q&A"/> it aims to take reality footage, politics, war, and other world events and combine them with the power of [[citizen journalism]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenewfreedom.net/wp/2008/05/19/interview-with-hayden-hewitt-co-founder-of-liveleakcom/ |title=Interview with Hayden Hewitt, Co-Founder of LiveLeak.com |accessdate=19 May 2008 |publisher= thenewfreedom.net |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310102810/http://www.thenewfreedom.net/wp/2008/05/19/interview-with-hayden-hewitt-co-founder-of-liveleakcom/ |archivedate=10 March 2011 |deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sundayherald.com/misc/print.php?artid=1122066 |title=Blair and Bush's latest weapon of war: YouTube |accessdate=13 January 2007 |work= [[Sunday Herald]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070212155331/http://www.sundayherald.com/misc/print.php?artid=1122066 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 12 February 2007}}</ref> Hayden Hewitt of [[Manchester]] is the only public member of LiveLeak's founding team.<ref name="Q&A">{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com.au/profile-of-hayden-hewitt-founder-of-liveleak-2014-10 | title=Q&A: The Man Behind LiveLeak, The Islamic State's Favourite Site For Beheading Videos | work=[[Business Insider]] Australia| date=7 November 2014 | accessdate=11 March 2017 | author=James Cook| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160316104436/http://www.businessinsider.com.au/profile-of-hayden-hewitt-founder-of-liveleak-2014-10 | archivedate=16 March 2016 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
== Controversy == [[File:US pilot mock-sings as missile hits target.theora.ogv|thumb|left|Cockpit video showing a [[Hellfire missile]] being fired at two targets in [[Afghanistan]].]]
Featured videos often involve graphic content of fatal accidents or shootings. Although by 2016, Liveleak had reduced its controversial content, the site frequently sparked up controversy up until around 2008, mostly due to its graphic and political content. The site came to prominence in 2007 following the unauthorised filming and leaking of the [[execution of Saddam Hussein]], and was referred to by [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Tony Snow]] and then-[[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[Tony Blair]].<ref>{{cite web|title=White House Press Secretary, Tony Snow, plugs LiveLeak|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=829607785c|publisher=liveleak.com|accessdate=23 March 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Tony Blair Plugs LiveLeak|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=73d671978f|publisher=liveleak.com|accessdate=23 March 2008}}</ref>
On 30 July 2007, the [[BBC]] programme ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' broadcast a show about how young people were getting physically assaulted and knocked unconscious.<ref>{{cite web|title=Panorama: Children's Fight Club|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2007/07_july/29/fight.shtml|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=23 March 2008}}</ref> When ''Panorama'' queried the "extremely violent videos" that had been posted to LiveLeak's website, co-founder Hayden Hewitt refused to take them down, stating, "Look all this is happening, this is real life, this is going on, we're going to show it."<ref>{{cite news|title=Web child fight videos criticised|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6920817.stm|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=23 March 2008 | date=29 July 2007}}</ref> LiveLeak states there are relatively few such videos on the site and should the uploaders be found to have participated in the violent attack or filmed it themselves, it would aid the police with any prosecutions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hayden Hewitts Response After the Panorama Show|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=ca4_1186119784|publisher=liveleak.com|accessdate=23 March 2008}}</ref>
LiveLeak was again in the spotlight in March 2008, when it hosted the anti-[[Quran]] film ''[[Fitna (film)|Fitna]]'' made by Dutch politician [[Geert Wilders]]. LiveLeak holds to being strictly non-biased in its approach to members and their content, believing in freedom of speech within the site rules, regardless of how certain content might offend them personally.<ref>{{cite web|title=LiveLeak, bias, and the eternal quest for personal accountability |url=http://forums.liveleak.com/blog.php?b=16 |publisher=liveleak.com |accessdate=23 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401001445/http://forums.liveleak.com/blog.php?b=16 |archivedate=1 April 2008 |df= }}</ref> ''Fitna'' was taken down after threats were made against LiveLeak staff, but was back online on 30 March 2008 after LiveLeak reportedly improved security. The video was once again removed two days later on 1 April; this time it was removed by the user citing that it was taken down due to copyright wrangles and a new version would be uploaded "soon."
A video of US journalist [[James Foley (photojournalist)|James Foley]] was posted by Islamist fighters on YouTube before, as reported by ''[[US News & World Report]]'', "YouTube deleted it and demand for the LiveLeak version soared."<ref>{{cite web|title=LiveLeak Bans Islamic State Beheading Videos After James Foley Murder |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/22/liveleak-bans-islamic-state-beheading-videos-after-james-foley-murder |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |accessdate=22 August 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140824115448/http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2014/08/22/liveleak-bans-islamic-state-beheading-videos-after-james-foley-murder |archivedate=24 August 2014 |df= }}</ref> In response to that video the leadership of the website declared that they would not host any "further beheadings carried out by [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|IS]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liveleak.com/view?i=a69_1408615973 |website= ''LiveLeak.com'' |title= Statement From Liveleak Regarding IS Beheading Videos which might be upcoming|date=21 August 2014|accessdate= 28 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="Q&A"/> The website will continue to host the original video that depicts the aftermath of Foley's execution.
==Features== "YourSay" is a section of the website where users upload their own videos, much like a [[vlog]]. Unlike YouTube, the vlogs on LiveLeak are more political and are known for debate.
LiveLeak currently has multiple categories including [[Syria]] and [[Ukraine]], in which graphic content regarding various conflicts can be viewed.<ref>{{cite web|title=LiveLeak|url=http://www.liveleak.com/|accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref>
== Partnerships == On 24 March 2014, LiveLeak and [[Ruptly]] announced a content partnership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prlog.org/12299623-ruptly-video-news-agency-and-liveleakcom-announce-content-partnership.html|title=Ruptly Video News Agency and LiveLeak.com announce content partnership|author=Ruptly|work=''prlog.org''}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Comparison of video hosting services]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category}} *{{Official website|http://liveleak.com }}
{{Video digital distribution platforms}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:LiveLeak}} [[Category:Citizen journalism]] [[Category:Entertainment websites]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2006]] [[Category:Video hosting]] [[Category:Video on demand services]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

{{Infobox language |name=Makury |altname=Makury Naga |nativename= |states=India, Burma |region=[[Nagaland]] |ethnicity= |speakers=65,000 |date=2014-16 |ref=e18 |familycolor=Sino-Tibetan |fam2=([[Tibeto-Burman languages|Tibeto-Burman]]) |fam3=[[Ao languages|Ao]]?
[[Tangkhulic languages|Tangkhulic]]? |iso3=jmn |glotto=maku1273 |glottorefname=Makury Naga }} '''Makury''', or '''Makury Naga''' (sometimes mistakenly spelled '''Makuri'''), is a [[Naga language]] of India and Burma. Shi (2009:3) and Saul (2005:25) suggest that Makury may be an [[Ao languages|Ao]] language. ==Classification== Makury is not close to other Naga languages that fall under Konyak-[Tangshang] and Angami-Zeme. Makury falls under Ao-Tangkhul linguistic group of southern Naga languages and is close to Naga languages that fall under the said language group. Müvlë (Longphuri) are a sub-tribe of Makury. In Eastern Nagaland, Myanmar, Makury, Somra Tangkhul and Para are closer than the other tribes in the north in terms of language (''Makury Tribal Council''). ==Geographical distribution== Makury is spoken in [[Leshi Township]], [[Homalin Township]], and [[Lahe Township]] in [[Hkamti District]], [[Sagaing Region]], [[Myanmar]]. There are about 40,000 speakers in Myanmar, and about 25,000 in India. ==Dialects== ''[[Ethnologue]]'' lists the following dialects of Makury. *Mëkheotlë *Sengphüvlë *Aralë *Jilë Jongphüvlë (listed as ''Kyaungphuri'' in Ethnologue) is a Makury clan name (''Makury Tribal Council''). Shi (2009:5) lists the following dialects of Makury. *Phuvle, Makheotle *Sengphuvle, Muvle, Jeile ==References== {{Reflist}} *Saul, Jamie D. 2005. ''The Naga of Burma: Their festivals, customs and way of life''. Bangkok, Thailand: Orchid Press. *Shi, Vong Tsuh. 2009. ''[http://inter.payap.ac.th/wp-content/uploads/linguistics_students/Vongs-thesis-May-2009_update2017.pdf Discourse studies of Makuri Naga narratives]''. MA thesis, Chiang Mai: Payap University. *Language and Social Development Organization (LSDO). 2006. ''A sociolinguistic survey of Makuri, Para, and Long Phuri Naga in Layshi Township, Myanmar''. Unpublished manuscript. {{Languages of Burma}} {{Languages of Northeast India}} {{Naga languages}} [[Category:Languages of Nagaland]] [[Category:Kuki-Chin–Naga languages]] [[Category:Languages of Myanmar]] {{st-lang-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox beauty pageant | photo = File: Miss Earth 2011 Olga Alava (Ecuador).jpg | caption = [[Olga Álava]], Miss Earth 2011 from [[Ecuador]] | winner = '''[[Olga Álava]]'''
'''{{flag|Ecuador}}''' | congeniality = [[Sanober Hussain]]
{{flag|Pakistan}} | photogenic = Cherry Liu
{{flag|Chinese Taipei|name=Chinese Taipei}} | best national costume = Tomoko Maeda
{{flag|Japan}} | date = 3 December 2011 | venue = [[University of the Philippines]] Theater, [[Quezon City]], [[Metro Manila]], [[Philippines]] | presenters = Jason Godfrey, [[Sonia Couling]] | acts = | broadcaster = [[ABS-CBN]], [[Studio 23]], [[The Filipino Channel]], [[STAR World]], [[Channel V]], [[Vietnam Television|VTV]] | entrants = 84{{cite web|url=http://www.missearth.tv/delegates.php |title=The Miss Earth Pageant |publisher=Missearth.tv}} | placements = 16 | withdraws = [[Cameroon]], [[Cayman Islands]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Egypt]], [[French Polynesia]], [[Guyana]], [[Jamaica]], [[Kenya]], [[Malta]], [[Mauritius]], [[Mongolia]], [[Nicaragua]], [[Poland]], [[Samoa]], [[Serbia]], [[South Sudan]], [[Tonga]] | debuts = [[Aruba]], [[Austria]], [[Sri Lanka]] | returns = [[Belize]], [[El Salvador]], [[Estonia]], [[Honduras]], [[Hungary]], [[Israel]], [[Pakistan]], [[Paraguay]], [[Portugal]], [[Spain]], [[Sweden]], [[Trinidad & Tobago]], [[U.S. Virgin Islands]], [[Zimbabwe]] | before = [[Miss Earth 2010|2010]] | next = [[Miss Earth 2012|2012]] }} '''Miss Earth 2011''' was held on 3 December 2011 at the [[University of the Philippines]] Theater in [[Diliman]], [[Quezon City]], Philippines.{{cite news|title=Ms. Earth moves from Bangkok to Manila|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/11/03/11/ms-earth-moves-bangkok-manila|accessdate=3 November 2011|newspaper=[[ABS-CBN]]|date=3 November 2011}} The show was aired live by [[Channel V]] at 8:00 pm, while [[Star World]] broadcast on Sunday, 4 December at 6:00 pm, [[ABS-CBN]] and [[Studio 23]] broadcast on the same day at 10:30 pm. There was also a delayed telecast of the show on [[The Filipino Channel]] and on the television stations of other participating countries.{{cite news|title=Miss Earth moves to Manila|url=http://www.tempo.com.ph/2011/ms-earth-moves-to-manila/#.TsMYimZ5Gpg|accessdate=16 November 2011|newspaper=Tempo|date=5 November 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111121212035/http://www.tempo.com.ph/2011/ms-earth-moves-to-manila/#.TsMYimZ5Gpg#.TsMYimZ5Gpg|archive-date=21 November 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The pageant was originally scheduled to be held at the [[Impact, Muang Thong Thani]] in [[Bangkok]], Thailand,{{cite news|last=CK Connection Co., Ltd.|first=News|title=Miss Earth 2011 in Thailand now set for December 3rd|url=http://www.thebahamasweekly.com/publish/international/Miss_Earth_2011_in_Thailand_now_set_for_December_3rd17900.shtml|accessdate=22 September 2011|newspaper=Tha bahamas Weekly|date=20 September 2011}}{{cite news|last=Requintina|first=Robert R.|title=2010 Miss Earth winners here|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/328381/2010-miss-earth-winners-here|accessdate=27 July 2011|newspaper=[[Manila Bulletin]]|date=27 July 2011}} however the pageant organizers decided to move the pageant back to the Philippines due to the [[2011 Thailand floods]].{{cite news|last=Requintina|first=Robert|title=Philippines will host Miss Earth|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/339940/philippines-will-host-miss-earth|accessdate=4 November 2011|newspaper=[[Manila Bulletin]]|date=3 November 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://www.missearth.tv/news.php#2011manila| title=Miss Earth 2011 moved to Manila due to mass flooding in Thailand| accessdate=30 October 2011}} [[Miss Earth 2010]], [[Nicole Faria]] of India, crowned her successor [[Olga Álava]] of Ecuador as Miss Earth 2011 at the end of the event.{{cite news|last=Jarloc|first=Glaiza|title=Ecuador wins Miss Earth 2011|url=http://www.sunstar.com.ph/manila/entertainment/2011/12/05/ecuador-wins-miss-earth-2011-194158|accessdate=5 February 2012|newspaper=Sun Star Manila|date=5 December 2011}}{{cite news|last=Mittra|first=Anwesha|title=Miss Ecuador crowned Miss Earth 2011|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-12-03/miss-india/30472081_1_miss-earth-fire-miss-earth-water-miss-earth-air|accessdate=5 February 2012|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=3 December 2011}} The three "elemental titles", which have equal ranking, were awarded to Miss Brazil Drielly Bennettone as Miss Earth-Air 2011, Miss Philippines [[Athena Imperial]] as Miss Earth-Water 2011 title, and [[Caroline Medina]] of Venezuela as Miss Earth-Fire 2011.{{cite news|last=Adina|first=Armin|title=Another UP grad lands beauty title, this time as Ms. Earth Water|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/23219/another-up-grad-lands-beauty-title-this-time-as-ms-earth-water|accessdate=5 February 2012|newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=4 December 2011}}{{cite news|last=Pagulong|first=Charmie Joy|title=Ecuador beauty named Miss Earth|url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=755233&publicationSubCategoryId=68|accessdate=5 February 2012|newspaper=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=5 December 2011}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news|last=Sieczkowski|first=Cavan|title=Miss Earth 2011 Crowned, Miss Ecuador Wins the Title|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/260869/20111204/miss-earth-2011-crowned-ecuador-wins-title.htm|accessdate=5 February 2012|newspaper=[[International Business #Brazil #Venezuela #Chinese Tapei #Crimea #Zimbabwe #Thailand #Slovenia #Mexico #Bosnia & Herzegovina #Ecuador #Philippines {{col-3}} ====Top 8==== #Crimea #Ecuador #Mexico #Philippines #Venezuela #Zimbabwe #Bosnia & Herzegovina #Brazil {{col-3}} ====Top 4==== #Ecuador #Brazil #Venezuela #Philippines {{col-end}} ==Winning answer== '''Final Question in Miss Earth 2011:''' "Why the candidates chose education as the environmental initiative that world leaders should prioritize?"{{cite news|last=Adina|first=Armin|title=Ecuadorian beauty crowned Miss Earth|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/25925/ecuadorian-beauty-crowned-miss-earth|accessdate=23 January 2012|newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=5 December 2011}} '''Answer of Miss Earth 2011:''' "Education is the best solution for the environment because children are those who have to preserve the Earth for future generations." – [[Olga Álava]], represented Ecuador.{{cite news|last=Sieczkowski|first=Cavan|title=Miss Earth 2011 Crowned, Miss Ecuador Wins the Title|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/260869/20111204/miss-earth-2011-crowned-ecuador-wins-title.htm|accessdate=23 January 2012|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=4 December 2011}} ==Judges== The board of judges during the final competition were consisted of the following personalities:{{cite news|last=Requintina|first=Robert R|title=Ecuadorian shines as 2011 Miss 2011}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%;" |- ! Catholicism; their treatment by Islamists and the authorities, including state protection (2008–2011)]. Refworld.org. Retrieved on 12 June 2016.{{cite book|author=Erwin Fahlbusch |title=The Encyclopedia of Christianity |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7ly4DgtT3LkC&pg=PA653 |year=2003 |publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing |isbn=978-0-8028-2415-8 |pages=653– |volume=3}} | related = Other [[Maghrebis]] }} '''Moroccans''' ({{Lang-ar|المغاربة}} ''al-Maġāriba'', [[Berber languages|Berber]]: {{lang|ber|ⵉⵎⵖⵕⴰⴱⵉⵢⵏ}} ''Imɣṛabiyen'') are a [[Maghrebis|Maghrebi]] ethnic group inhabiting or originating from [[Morocco]] that share a common [[Culture of Morocco|Moroccan culture]] and [[Maghrebis|Maghrebi]] ancestry. The overwhelming majority of Moroccans are of [[Arab-Berber]] descent;{{cite book|authors=Tej K. Bhatia, William C. Ritchie|title=The Handbook of Bilingualism|date=2006|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=0631227350|page=860|url=https://www.google.com/books?id=pNqVaUk4dM0C&pg=PA860|accessdate=18 July 2017}} however, many identify as [[Arabs]] or [[Arabized Berber|Arabized Berbers]]. In addition to the 36 million Moroccans in [[Morocco]], there is a large [[Moroccan diaspora]] in [[France]], [[Belgium]], [[Israel]], [[Italy]], the [[Moroccan-Dutch|Netherlands]] and [[Moroccans in Spain|Spain]], and a smaller one in the [[British Moroccans|United Kingdom]], the [[Moroccan American|United States]], [[Canada]], the [[Arabian Peninsula]] and in other [[Arab states]]. A sizeable part of the Moroccan diaspora is composed of [[Moroccan Jews]]. == History == [[File:Iberomaurisiense-Capsiense.png|thumb|200px|{{legend|#01DFD7|[[Capsian culture]]}}{{legend|#1a8000|Iberomaurusian culture}}]] The first [[anatomically modern humans]] (''[[Homo sapiens sapiens]]'') in North Africa are the makers of the [[Aterian]], a [[Middle Stone Age]] (or [[Middle Paleolithic|Middle Palaeolithic]]) stone tool [[Archaeological industry|culture]]. The earliest Aterian lithic assemblages date to around 145,000 years ago, and were discovered at the site of Ifri n'Ammar in Morocco. This industry was followed by the [[Iberomaurusian]] culture, a backed bladelet industry found throughout the Maghreb. It was originally described in 1909 at the site of Abri Mouillah. Other names for this [[Cro-Magnon]]-associated culture include ''Mouillian'' and ''Oranian''. The [[Epipaleolithic]] Iberomaurusian makers were centred in prehistoric sites, such as [[Taforalt]] and [[Mechta-Afalou]]. They were succeeded by the [[Capsian culture|Capsians]]. The Capsian culture is often thought to have arrived in Africa from the Near East, although it is also suggested that the Iberomaurusians may have been the progenitors of the Capsians. Around 5000 BC, the populations of North Africa were primarily descended from the makers of the Iberomaurusian and Capsian cultures, with a more recent intrusion associated with the [[Neolithic revolution]].J. Desanges, "The proto-Berbers" 236-245, at 237, in ''General History of Africa, v.II Ancient Civilizations of Africa'' (UNESCO 1990). The proto-Berber tribes evolved from these prehistoric communities during the Late Bronze to Early Iron Age.Mário Curtis Giordani, ''História da África. Anterior aos descobrimentos'' (Petrópolis, Brasil: Editora Vozes 1985) at 42-43, 77-78. Giordani references Bousquet, ''Les Berbères'' (Paris 1961). == Ethnic groups == Moroccans are primarily of [[Berbers|Berber]] origin, like other neighboring [[Maghreb people|Maghrebians]]. As such, Berbers are descendants of the prehistoric populations of [[Morocco]] through the [[Iberomaurusian]]s and [[Capsian culture|Capsians]]. The [[Afroasiatic languages|Afroasiatic]] family may have originated in the [[Mesolithic]] period, perhaps in the context of the [[Capsian culture]].Abdallah Laroui, ''The History of the Maghrib'' (Paris 1970; Princeton 1977) at 17, 60 (re S.W.Asians, referencing the earlier work of Gsell).{{Citation|last=Camps|first=Gabriel|title=''Les Berbères''|year=1996|pages=11–14, 65|publisher=Edisud}} By 5000 BC, the populations of Morocco were an amalgamation of [[Ibero-Maurisian]] and a minority of [[Capsian]] stock blended with a more recent intrusion associated with the [[Neolithic revolution]].J. Desanges, "The proto-Berbers" 236–245, at 237, in ''General History of Africa, v.II Ancient Civilizations of Africa'' (UNESCO 1990). Out of these populations, the proto-[[Berbers|Berber]] tribes formed during the late [[Paleolithic]] era.Mário Curtis Giordani, ''História da África. Anterior aos descobrimentos'' (Petrópolis, Brasil: Editora Vozes 1985) at 42–43, 77–78. Giordani references Bousquet, ''Les Berbères'' (Paris 1961). Berber-speaking groups include the [[Riffian people|Riffians]], [[Shilha people|Shilha]] and [[Zayanes]]. Arabic-speaking groups include the [[Jebala people|Jebala]] in the north and [[Sahrawi people|Sahrawiyin]] in the southeast. A small minority of the population is identified as [[Haratin]] and [[Gnawa]]. These are sedentary agriculturalists of non-Berber origin, who inhabit the southern and eastern oases and speak either Berber or Moroccan Arabic. Between the [[Nile]] and the [[Red Sea]] were living [[Arab]] tribes expelled from [[Arabia]] for their turbulence, [[Banu Hilal]] and [[Banu Sulaym|Sulaym]], who often plundered farming areas in the [[Nile Valley]].{{cite web|title=Ibn Khaldun, laudateur et contempteur des Arabes|url=http://www.persee.fr/doc/remmm_0035-1474_1966_num_2_1_933|website=Persee.fr|accessdate =1 October 2015}} According to [[Ibn Khaldun]], whole tribes set off with women, children, ancestors, animals and camping equipment. ==Genetic composition== [[File:Y_Hap_EM-81.PNG|thumb|Distribution of the haplogroup [[Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)|E1b1b-M81]], the most common paternal lineage among Moroccans.]] {| style="text-align:center;" class="wikitable sortable" ! [[Riffian people|Riffians]] (North [[Morocco]]) || AA (Berber) || 54 || 0 || 95.9 || — || 0 || 0 || 0 || 0 || — || — || 0 || Dugoujon et al. 2005J.-M. Dugoujon and G. Philippson (2005) [http://www.ddl.ish-lyon.cnrs.fr/Fulltext/philippson/AUSSOIS_2005_final.pdf The Berbers. Linguistic and genetic diversity]. CNRS. |- ! {{Interlanguage link multi|Béni-Snassen|fr}} (Northern [[Morocco]]) || AA (Berber) & (Semitic) || 67 || 0 || 95.1 || — || 0 || 0 || 0 || 0 || — || — || 0 || Dugoujon et al. 2005 |} ==Culture== {{main article|Culture of Morocco}} [[File:Maroc Marrakech Bahia Luc Viatour 3.jpg|thumb|right|120px|A Moroccan ''[[kaftan]]'']] Through [[History of Morocco|Moroccan history]], the country had many cultural influences (Europe, Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa). The culture of Morocco shares similar traits with those of neighboring countries, particularly Algeria and Tunisia and to a certain extent Spain. Morocco influenced modern day Europe, in several fields, from architecture to agriculture, and the introduction of [[Moroccan numbers]], widely used now in the world{{Citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=October 2017}}. Each region possesses its own uniqueness, contributing to the national culture. Morocco has set among its top priorities the protection of its diversity and the preservation of its cultural heritage. The traditional dress for men and women is called ''[[djellaba]]'', a long, loose, hooded garment with full sleeves. For special occasions, men also wear a red cap called a bernousse, more commonly known as a [[fez]]. Women wear [[kaftan]]s decorated with ornaments. Nearly all men, and most women, wear [[balgha]] (بلغه). These are soft leather slippers with no heel, often dyed yellow. Women also wear high-heeled sandals, often with silver or gold tinsel. Moroccan style is a new trend in decoration, which takes its roots from [[Moorish architecture]]. It has been made popular by the vogue of [[Moroccan riad|riad]] renovation in Marrakech. Dar is the name given to one of the most common types of domestic structures in Morocco; it is a home found in a medina, or walled urban area of a city. Most Moroccan homes traditionally adhere to the Dar al-Islam, a series of tenets on Islamic domestic life. Dar exteriors are typically devoid of ornamentation and windows, except occasional small openings in secondary quarters, such as stairways and service areas. These piercings provide light and ventilation. [[Moroccan cuisine]] primarily consists of a blend of Berber, Moorish and Arab influences. It is known for dishes like [[couscous]] and [[pastilla]], among others. Spices such as cinnamon are also used in Moroccan cooking. Sweets like [[halwa]] are popular, as well as other confections. Cuisines from neighbouring areas have also influenced the country's culinary traditions. Additionally, Moroccan craftsmanship has a rich tradition of jewellery-making, pottery, leather-work and woodwork. The music of Morocco ranges and differs according to the various areas of the country. Moroccan music has a variety of styles from complex sophisticated orchestral music to simple music involving only voice and drums. There are three varieties of Berber folk music: village and ritual music, and the music performed by professional musicians. [[Chaabi (Morocco)|Chaabi]] (الشعبي) is a music consisting of numerous varieties which descend from the multifarious forms of Moroccan folk music. Chaabi was originally performed in markets, but is now found at any celebration or meeting. [[Gnawa music|Gnawa]] is a form of music that is mystical. It was gradually brought to Morocco by the Gnawa and later became part of the Moroccan tradition. [[Sufism|Sufi]] brotherhoods ([[Tariqa|tarikas]]) are common in Morocco, and music is an integral part of their spiritual tradition. This music is an attempt at reaching a trance state which inspires mystical ecstasy. ==Languages== {{main article|Languages of Morocco}} [[File:Morocco - Linguistic map.png|right|300px|thumb|Linguistic map of Morocco]] Morocco's official languages are [[Classical Arabic]] and [[Standard Moroccan Berber|Berber]]. The majority of the population speaks [[Moroccan Arabic]]. More than 12 million Moroccans speak Berber varieties, either as a first language or bilingually with Moroccan Arabic. Three different Berber dialects are spoken: [[Riffian language|Riff]], [[Shilha language|Shilha]] (Chleuh) and [[Central Atlas Tamazight]]. [[Hassaniya Arabic]] is spoken in the southern part of the country. Morocco has recently included the protection of Hassaniya in the constitution as part of the July 2011 reforms. [[French language|French]] is taught universally and still serves as Morocco's primary language of [[:Category:Companies of Morocco|commerce]] and [[Economy of Morocco|economics]]; it is also widely used in education, sciences, government and most education fields. [[Spanish language|Spanish]] is also spoken by some in the northern part of the country as a foreign language. Meanwhile, [[English language|English]] is increasingly becoming more popular among the educated, particularly in the science fields. ==See also== *[[Moroccan diaspora]] *[[Genetic history of the Iberian Peninsula]] *[[Morisco|Moriscos]] *[[Expulsion of the Moriscos]] *{{commons category inline|People of Morocco}} *[[List of Moroccans]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Demographics of Morocco}} {{Morocco topics}} {{Moroccan diaspora}} [[Category:Moroccan diaspora]] [[Category:Moroccan society]] [[Category:Arabs in Morocco]] [[Category:Arabs]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Morocco]] [[Category:North African people]]

There are hundreds of '''Pakistanis in Indonesia''', mainly of [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] origin, who work in various textile and rice production industries. Statistics from the [[Overseas Pakistanis Foundation]] in 2004 outlined as many as 400<ref>[http://www.opf.org.pk/download/anual/YEARBK.pdf Overseas Pakistanis Foundation - 2004 Yearbook] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524170403/http://www.opf.org.pk/download/anual/YEARBK.pdf |date=2010-05-24 }}</ref> although numbers have grown; roughly 100 Pakistani families reside in [[Jakarta]] and another 300 in other cities. Additionally, there is a large second and third generation of individuals, originally descendants of Pakistani soldiers who came to fight in 1945 as part of the [[British Indian Army]] alongside the Indonesian military against the [[Axis forces]] and the [[Japanese occupation of Indonesia|Japanese]].<ref>[http://thejakartaglobe.com/justAdded/my-jakarta-maj-gen-ret-ali-baz/269660 My Jakarta: Maj. Gen. (ret.) Ali Baz] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503125349/http://www.thejakartaglobe.com/justAdded/my-jakarta-maj-gen-ret-ali-baz/269660 |date=2012-05-03 }} - [[The Jakarta Globe]]</ref>
==Notable people== * [[Mowahid Shah]], Pakistan attorney-at-law, author and policy analyst * [[Emilia Contessa]] (b. 1957), actress, pop singer, politician * [[Asif Sandila]] (b. 1954), retired 4-star rank Pakistani admiral, attended [[Indonesian Navy]]'s Naval Command and Staff College. * [[Raline Shah]] (b. 1985), actress
==See also== * [[Pakistan-Indonesia relations]] * [[Indonesians in Pakistan]]

{{Infobox ethnic group |group=Portuguese Angolan
''Luso-Angolano'' |population= ~220,000 (2014){{cite web|title=José Eduardo dos Santos diz que trabalhadores portugueses são bem-vindos em Angola|url=http://www.observatorioemigracao.secomunidades.pt/np4/3607.html|publisher=Observatório da Emigração|accessdate=22 July 2013|quote=…presença de cerca de 200 mil trabalhadores portugueses no país…}} |popplace= [[Luanda]], [[Benguela]] |langs= [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], a small minority having some mastery of [[Kimbundu]], [[South Mbundu language|Umbundu]], [[Kikongo language|Kikongo]], and other [[Bantu languages]] |rels= [[Christianity]] (predominantly [[Roman Catholic]]) |related= [[Portuguese people]], [[Portuguese Brazilian]], [[Brazilian people|Brazilians]], [[Portuguese Africans]]}} '''Portuguese Angolan''' ({{lang-pt|luso-angolano}}) is a [[Portuguese people|person of Portuguese descent]] born or permanently living in [[Angola]]. ==History== {{Historical populations|type=|percentages = pagr | 1845| 1832 | 1900| 9198 | 1920| 20200 | 1940| 44083 | 1950| 78826 | 1960| 172529 | 1961| 162387 | 1970| 290000 | 1974| 335000 | 1976| 40000 |footnote={{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G8j5ja5mOFEC|title=Angola Under the Portuguese: The Myth and the Reality|last=Bender|first=Gerald J.|date=1978-01-01|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520032217|page=228|language=en}} }} In 1482, Portuguese caravels commanded by [[Diogo Cão]] arrived in the [[Kingdom of Kongo]]. Other expeditions followed, and close relations were soon established between the two states. The Portuguese brought firearms and many other technological advances, as well as a new religion (Christianity); in return, the King of the Congo offered plenty of slaves, ivory, and minerals. The Portuguese colony of Angola was founded in 1575 with the arrival of Paulo Dias de Novais with a hundred families of colonists and four hundred soldiers. Luanda was granted the status of city in 1605. Many Portuguese settlers married native Africans resulting in a mixed-race (''[[mulato]]'', later generally called ''mestiço'') population. Angola was declared a formal [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese province]] in the 19th century, but only in the early 20th century did the mainland government allow large-scale white emigration and settlement to Angola and its other provinces. In 1960, Angola had up to 172,000 Portuguese settlers,{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G8j5ja5mOFEC|title=Angola Under the Portuguese: The Myth and the Reality|last=Bender|first=Gerald J.|date=1978-01-01|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520032217|page=228|language=en}} who significantly contributed to its economy. The majority of whom came from rural agrarian backgrounds in Portugal who saw engaging in commerce in Angola as one of the few means of [[Social mobility|upward social mobility]] available to them.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G8j5ja5mOFEC|title=Angola Under the Portuguese: The Myth and the Reality|last=Bender|first=Gerald J.|date=1978-01-01|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520032217|page=233|language=en}} As the [[Angolan war of independence]] began in 1961, triggering off a late colonial development of Angola, there was an influx of Portuguese military personnel, as well as civil servants and other people.Contrary to the settlers which often had lived in Angola for two or even three generations, the Portuguese arriving during the last phase of colonial occupation did not become identified with Angola. As a consequence, the number of Portuguese living in Angola went up to about 350,000.Gerald J.Bender & P. Stanley Yoder, "Whites in Angola on the Eve of Independence", ''Africa Today', 21 (4) 1974, pp. 23 - 37'' This number would have been higher, had a significant part of the settlers not left for other countries, especially [[Namibia]], [[Brazil]], [[South Africa]] and the [[United States]]. While most whites then living in Angola sided with Portugal's efforts to suppress the anti-colonial revolt, a minority sympathized with the nationalist movements, and a few even joined them in their fight. The Angolan author [[Pepetela]] is among these. When the [[António de Oliveira Salazar|Salazar]] regime in Portugal was abolished by a military coup in Portugal, in 1974, and independence was granted to the colonies by the new government, whites overwhelmingly left Angola after independence in 1975. Most of them went to [[Portugal]], where they were called [[History of Portugal (1974-1986)#The retornados|''retornados'']] and were not always welcomed, while others moved to neighboring Namibia (then a [[South Africa]]n territory), South Africa or Brazil,[https://imigrantes.no.sapo.pt/page6portugal.html Portuguese Immigration (History)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6GrrUiDTj?url=http://imigrantes.no.sapo.pt/page6portugal.html |date=2013-05-25 }} or United States. It is estimated that around 250,000 left the country in 1975 and by 1976 only 30,000 to 40,000 remained in Angola.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G8j5ja5mOFEC|title=Angola Under the Portuguese: The Myth and the Reality|last=Bender|first=Gerald J.|date=1978-01-01|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520032217|page=236|language=en}} Among the departed Portuguese civilians, many were able to take with them only a single suitcase, while some were able to dispatch their household goods and even cars by ship. The majority left everything behind.{{cite news |last= |first=Kutemba |date= 19 October 2008 |title=Angola: Sobre a alegria e tristeza de ser um retornado |url=https://pt.globalvoices.org/2008/10/19/angola-sobre-a-alegria-e-tristeza-de-ser-um-retornado/ |newspaper=Global Voices |location=International |access-date=21 October 2015}} They boarded planes at Luanda's Craveiro Lopes Airport at the rate of 500 a day{{clarify|date=October 2015}}, but there were not enough flights to cover demand.{{Cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913229-4,00.html|title=MOZAMBIQUE: Dismantling the Portuguese Empire|date=1975-07-07|work=Time|access-date=2017-07-24|language=en-US|issn=0040-781X}} On arrival in Portugal, those who had been able to draw their savings in Angola could not exchange more than 5,000 Angolan esculos (about USD 200) into Portuguese escudos.{{cn|date=August 2016}} Back in Angola, the new government gave all remaining Portuguese settlers a few months period to choose between Angolan citizenship or to leave the country. A significant minority of them opted for Angola and some of them actively took part in the [[Angolan Civil War]], generally on the side of the [[MPLA]]. After Angola abandoned in 1991 the socialist regime adopted at independence in 1975, many Portuguese Angolans returned to Angola. Due to Angola's economic boom, which started in the 1990s, an increasing number of Portuguese without previous attachment to Angola have migrated to Angola for economic reasons, most importantly the [[Economy of Angola|recent national economic boom]].[http://tv1.rtp.pt/noticias/?article=186757&headline=20&visual=9], ''Radio Televisão Portuguesa'', September 13, 2008 As of 2008, Angola was the preferred destination for Portuguese migrants in Africa. Portuguese nationals numbered an estimated 120,000 in 2011, reaching about 200,000 in 2013. ==Notable people== [[File:Pep.jpg|thumb|[[Pepetela]]]] Notable Angolan people of Portuguese descent include: * [[Pepetela]], writer * [[Paulo Figueiredo]], footballer * [[Ricardo Teixeira (racing driver)|Ricardo Teixeira]], racing driver * [[José Eduardo Agualusa]], writer * [[Luandino Vieira]], writer * [[Ana Paula Ribeiro Tavares]] writer, historian * [[Xesko]], artist ==Language and religion== Their native language is Portuguese, which today is the [[official language]] and [[lingua franca]] of Angola. Their communities existing in Luanda, Benguela and Moçâmedes spoke until the early 20th-century European (in Benguela: initially Brazilian) Portuguese mixed with numerous elements from African languages, especially Kimbundu and Umbundu. In the course of the 20th century, due to the waves of new settlers arriving from Portugal, their language became practically identical with European Portuguese. Some Portuguese Angolans have a lesser or greater mastery of one of the [[Bantu languages]] – notably [[Kimbundu]], [[South Mbundu language|Umbundu]], and [[Kikongo language|Kikongo]] – but their number has diminished dramatically after independence, and hardly anybody now uses an African language as second languages. Many educated Portuguese Angolans learnt [[French language|French]] and, less intensely, [[English language|English]] during the colonial period; since independence, white as well as black educated people generally learn English, while French has faded into the background. The vast majority of Portuguese Angolans are [[Christianity|Christians]], mostly [[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholics]], although many of them do not practice their religion. A very small number of them are [[Judaism|Jews]], whose ancestors escaped the [[Inquisition]]. ==See also== *[[White Angolans]] *''[[Lusotropicalismo]]'' *[[Luso-Africans]] **''[[Assimilados]]'' **''[[Lançados]]'' **[[Mestiço#Mestiço – Angola|Angolan mestiços]] **''[[Órfãs d'El-Rei]]'' *[[Angolar language]] *''[[Angolanidade]]'' *[[Angolans in Portugal]] **''[[Retornados]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.economist.com/world/mideast-africa/displayStory.cfm?story_id=12079340 Flight from Angola], ''The Economist'', August 16, 1975 {{Ethnic groups in Angola}} {{Portuguese diaspora}} [[Category:Angolan people of Portuguese descent| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Angola]] [[Category:Portuguese diaspora in Africa|Angola]]

{{Infobox company | name = Public News Service | logo = Public New Service Logo.jpg | type = [[B Corporation (certification)]] | industry = [[News media]] | foundation = {{Start date|1996|}} | location_city = [[Boulder]], [[Colorado]] U.S. | key_people = Lark Corbeil {{small|(Founder, Publisher)}} | homepage = {{URL|publicnewsservice.org/}} }}
'''Public News Service''' (usually shortened to '''PNS''') was launched in 1996 by journalist Lark Corbeil in Idaho. Today, PNS has 37 state-based news services that provide multi-platform content for free to news outlets as a way to advocate journalism in the public interest.<ref name="Alternet">{{cite news|title=Heir America |url=https://www.alternet.org/story/22277/heir_america |publisher=[[Alternet]]|date=June 24, 2005|accessdate=2017-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Q&A: Public News Service founder on ‘whirlwind’ since reporter’s arrest|url=https://www.cjr.org/united_states_project/tom-price-reporter-arrest-trump.php|publisher=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|date=2017-05-17|accessdate=2017-12-08}}</ref>
==History==
Following the [[1996 Telecommunications Act]], which allowed for media cross-ownership,<ref name="fcc.gov">The Telecommunications Act of 1996. Title 3, sec. 301. Retrieved from [http://www.fcc.gov/Reports/tcom1996.pdf fcc.gov] (2011)</ref> Corbeil founded Public News Service as an avenue to examine and reach rural areas.<ref name =[[BizWest]]>{{cite news|title=Stories of Solutions|url=http://www.bizwest.com/2016/08/19/stories-of-solutions|publisher=[[bizwest]]|date=2017-08-19|accessdate=2017-12-08}}</ref>
In May 2017, Dan Heyman, a PNS producer in West Virginia, was arrested at the state capitol for asking former Health and Human Services Secretary [[Tom Price (American politician)|Tom Price]] a question in an “aggressive manner.” Heyman was jailed and charged for willful disruption of state government processes.<ref>{{cite news|title=HHS secretary says police ‘did what they felt was appropriate’ in arresting a West Virginia journalist|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/05/10/west-virginia-journalist-arrested-after-asking-hhs-secretary-tom-price-a-question/|publisher=[[Washington Post]]|date=May 11, 2017|accessdate=2017-12-08}}</ref> In September 2017, the misdemeanor charge against Heyman was dropped after “a careful review” by the [[Kanawha County]] prosecutor’s office.<ref>{{cite news|title=Charge Dropped Against Reporter Who Questioned Tom Price|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/06/business/media/tom-price-journalist-arrest.html|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=September 6, 2017|accessdate=2017-12-08}}</ref>
==Funding==
Public News Service, a certified [[B Corporation]], is funded by grants, gifts, some media contributions, and memberships from individuals, foundations, non-profit organizations and socially responsibly businesses.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bcorporation.net/community/public-news-service|title=B Corporation Community|date=2017-07-01|accessdate=2017-12-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=HHS secretary says police ‘did what they felt was appropriate’ in arresting a West Virginia journalist|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2017/05/10/west-virginia-journalist-arrested-after-asking-hhs-secretary-tom-price-a-question/|publisher=[[Washington Post]]|date=May 11, 2017|accessdate=2017-12-08}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Forms of government}} A '''puppet state''' is a [[Nation state|state]] that is [[De jure|''de jure'']] independent but is [[De facto|''de facto'']] completely dependent upon an outside power.<ref name="Marek">{{cite book|last=Marek|first=Krystyna|title=Identity and Continuity of States in Public International Law|year=1954|publisher=Library Droz|isbn=9782600040440|page=178}}</ref> It is nominally [[Sovereign state|sovereign]] but effectively controlled by a foreign or otherwise alien power, for reasons such as financial interests.<ref name="McNeely1995">{{cite book|last=McNeely|first=Connie L.|title=Constructing the Nation-state: International Organization and Prescriptive Action|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8JKEj94TsP4C&pg=PA61|accessdate=13 September 2017|year=1995|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-29398-6|page=61|quote=The term 'puppet state' is used to describe nominal sovereigns under effective foreign control...}}</ref>
A puppet state preserves the external paraphernalia of independence like a name, flag, anthem, constitution, law codes, motto and government but in reality is an organ of another state which created, sponsored or otherwise controls the government of the puppet state.<ref name="Raic2002">{{cite book|last=Raič|first=David|title=Statehood and the Law of Self-Determination|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L7UOyPGYBkwC&pg=PA81|accessdate=13 September 2017|year=2002|publisher=Kluwer Law International|isbn=90-411-1890-X|page=81}}</ref> Puppet states are not recognized as [[legitimacy (political)|legitimate]] under [[international law]].<ref name="Lemkin2008">{{cite book|last=Lemkin|first=Raphael|authorlink=Raphael Lemkin|title=Axis Rule in Occupied Europe: Laws of Occupation, Analysis of Government, Proposals for Redress|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y0in2wOY-W0C&pg=PA11|accessdate=13 September 2017|year=2008|publisher=The Lawbook Exchange, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-58477-901-8|page=11}}</ref>
== Etymology of the term == In the [[Middle Ages]] [[vassal state]]s existed which were based on delegation of rule of a country from a King to noble men of lower rank. Since the [[Peace of Westphalia]] of 1648 the concept of a nation came into existence where [[Westphalian sovereignty|sovereignty]] was connected more to the people who inhabited the land than to the nobility who owned the land. The term is a metaphor which compares a state or government to a puppet controlled by an outside puppeteer using strings.<ref>{{cite book |title=Ultra Hush-hush |last=Shapiro |first=Stephen |year=2003 |publisher=Annick Press |isbn=1-55037-778-7 |page=38 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iH6gFG1v-kUC&pg=PA38&dq |quote=Puppet state: a country whose government is being controlled by the government of another country, much as a puppeteer controls the strings on a marionette }}</ref> The first recorded use of the term "puppet government" is from 1884, in reference to the [[Khedivate of Egypt]].<ref name=etymoline>{{cite web|last1=Harper|first1=Douglas|title=puppet (n.)|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=puppet&allowed_in_frame=0|website=Online Etymology Dictionary|accessdate=1 June 2014}}</ref>
== 19th century == The [[Batavian Republic]] was established in the Netherlands under French revolutionary protection.
In Eastern Europe, France established a Polish client state of the [[Duchy of Warsaw]].
In Italy, republics were created in the late 18th and early 19th centuries with the assistance and encouragement of [[First French Empire|Napoleonic France]]. See also [[French client republic]]s.
In 1836 U.S. citizens allowed to live in the Mexican state of Texas revolted against the Mexican government to establish a U.S.-backed [[Republic of Texas]], a country that existed less than 10 years (from May 14, 1836 to December 29, 1845) before it was annexed to the United States of America. However, in August 1837, [[Memucan Hunt, Jr.]], the Texan minister to the United States, submitted the first official annexation proposal to the [[Martin van Buren|Van Buren]] administration (the first American-led attempts to take over Mexican Texas [[Long Expedition|by filibustering date back to 1819]] and [[Fredonian Rebellion|by separatist settlers since 1826]]).
In 1896 [[United Kingdom|Britain]] [[Anglo-Zanzibar War|established a state]] in [[Zanzibar]].
== World War I == *[[Kingdom of Poland (1916–1918)|Kingdom of Poland]] (1916–1918) – The Central Powers' forces occupied [[Russian Empire|Russian]] [[Congress Poland]] in 1915 and in 1916 the [[German Empire]] and [[Austria-Hungary]] created a Polish Monarchy in order to exploit the occupied territories in an easier way and mobilize the Poles against the Russians (see [[Polish Legions in World War I|Polish Legions]]). In 1918 the state became independent and formed the backbone of the new internationally recognized [[Second Polish Republic]]. *[[Kingdom of Lithuania (1918)]] – after Russia's defeat, the Germans established a Lithuanian kingdom. However it became [[Republic of Lithuania (1918-1940)|an independent republic]] with Germany's defeat. *[[Duchy of Courland and Semigallia (1918)]] – in 1915 the Imperial German forces occupied the [[Russian Empire|Russian]] [[Courland Governorate]] and the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (Russia–Central Powers)|Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] ended the [[Eastern Front of World War I|war in the east]], so the local ethnic [[Baltic Germans]] established a Duchy under the German crown from that part of [[Ober Ost]], with a common return of civil administration in favor of military. This state was very swiftly merged with the [[Baltic State Duchy]], and German-occupied territories of [[Russian Empire]] in Livonia and Estonia, into a multi-ethnic [[United Baltic Duchy]]. *[[Kingdom of Finland (1918)]] – A short-lived monarchy in Finland after the end of [[Grand Duchy of Finland|czarist rule]]. * [[Provisional National Government of the Southwestern Caucasus]] and [[Provisional Government of Western Thrace]] were the provisional republics that were established by the Turkish minorities in Thrace and Caucasia, after the [[Ottoman Empire]] lost its lands in these regions. Both were the products of the Ottoman Intelligence agency, Teşkilat-ı Mahsusa, in terms of organisational structure and organisers, and they had remarkably common features.<ref name="Sirin">{{cite journal|format=PDF|last=Şirin|first=İbrahim|url=http://www.historystudies.net/dergi/tar201512901a7.pdf|title=İki Hükümet Bir Teşkilat: Garbî Trakya Hükümet-i Muvakkatesi’nden Cenub-î Garbî Kafkas Hükümeti Muvakkate- î Milliyesi’ne|trans-title=Two Governments One Organisation: From the Provisional Government of Western Thrace to the Provisional Government of South-Western Caucasia|language=tr|journal=History Studies International: Journal of History|publisher=historystudies.net|volume=6|issue=2|date=February 2014|issn=1309-4688|doi=10.9737/historys1130|pages=125–142|postscript=: See translated abstract on page 125}}</ref>
